At dawn, Dover pretended to be a postcard again. The chalk edge of the cliff cut the sky cleanly; the gulls were already up and arguing about something nobody else could get worked up about, and the sea, in its endless shrug, slapped against the harbour wall as if to say, there you go, have another go, let’s see. Hannah had been awake since five-thirty. It wasn’t nerves, not exactly. Just that a thread ran through her—silver, taut—that pulled her up out of bed before the alarm, tugging her along toward the day.

She made tea and stood by the kitchen window, sipping it black. Her terrace had a view of the ferry lanes if she craned a bit, and when she did, a ship the size of a quiet thought drifted across the rectangle of sea. Somewhere, inside that big white thing full of strangers and cartons of goods and thick ropes and blinking lights, somebody was probably also drinking tea, scalding their lip, thinking about a Tuesday that had arrived just like that. Hannah smiled at the idea that her own thoughts might be mirrored by some passing stranger. It made the morning softer.

In the classroom, the tidy fish tank hummed. The filter kept up its ghost-whisper, the heater lamp glowed like a tiny amber sun. Inside, her small geniuses flickered: neon tetras, wobbly zebra danios, and six guppies that had started out as three. Babies spent half their lives getting born, Hannah thought. People spent the other half finding their way back to a place where they could be simple again. She untied her scarf and hung it on the back of the chair. On the whiteboard she wrote the day and a quote in peculiar purple: “Literature is news that stays news.” —Ezra Pound. Then, underneath, in smaller script: Plus, we will not set the classroom on fire today, 9C.

“Promise me,” she said out loud to the empty desks.

The guppy with the stubby dorsal, the one with a blotch like a thumbprint on his tail, waggled nearer to the glass and gave her a hard little bead eye. This was the boss of the guppies; she’d named him after a soldier from an old story she loved. Galahad was too grand. She shortened it. Gal.

“Morning, Gal,” she told him. “Be kind to the others today. No nipping. Not hilarious. Not cute.”

He flicked sideways, showed her his sheen, and took a ceremonial bite at a bubble. He was the most temperamental of her small universe. If fish could brood, Gal brooded, tiny and serious. The science teacher down the hall had told her guppies could be territorial in tanks, and sometimes, if they saw their reflection, they’d posture at it all day. “Like men in gyms,” Mr. Shaw had said, balancing microwaved porridge and optimism in one hand.

It was, properly, Mr. Shaw who had introduced the tank as a calming presence for the students—well-being, reduced anxiety, regulated breathing. But feeding them had become Hannah’s small meditation. The students thought she’d set up the tank to teach them empathy, which was a pleasant rumor she never corrected.

The first bell spilled bodies along the corridor. Teenagers arrived in drifts, hair damp, shoes squeaking. They came into her room carrying armfuls of their waking lives: a basketball, the taste of rushed toast, a worry about a family member said sideways. She saw it all like flash cards. They were hers. Not really, not legally or forever, but for being thirteen and fourteen and hopelessly proud about washing their face now and then, they belonged to her for sixty minutes a day. She was both carried and tugged by this—she didn’t go around naming it love in case anybody overheard and thought she might be weak.

“Miss Flint, Miss Flint,” Noah said, two steps into the room, skipping the whole greeting scheme. “If a character lies to another character, and then something bad happens to them, do we assume the author is telling us lying is bad?”

“Whoa,” she said. “Good morning to you too. Put your bag down, Noah. Do we assume that?”

“I did in the homework,” he said, in a way that was both hopeful and defensive. “Do not call my mother.”

“I think the author is telling you that choices have consequences. But lying isn’t always wrong in literature, or in life. Sometimes it saves someone.”

Safia came past and rolled her eyes at the fish. “Miss, that one’s aggy.”

“Oh?” Hannah looked at Gal, who was indeed performing a tiny, indignant dance at the glass.

“I walked past and he swam at me like he wanted beef,” Safia said, twirling her pen. “He knows what he did.”

“He knows nothing,” Hannah said. “He’s a fish.”

“Are you sure?” Safia smirked. “Because he seems to know something. He’s got that look.”

“You have that look,” Noah muttered, flipping open his English folder, where he always drew a little dragon in the top corner before he wrote a sentence.

It was a good class. For most of the period, they did not set anything on fire. They argued, with zeal, about whether Macbeth was a weak man pushed by a violent woman, or a violent man full stop. They wrote in that fervent way they had, where their handwriting went sideways as if chasing a thought down a corridor. When she read what they wrote, she saw little glimmers. Not genius, not the kind you could swallow whole and be saved by forever. She saw care. Care looked like the moment a student crossed out an extra adjective and left a sentence cleaner. Care looked like when the boy with the loudest laugh stayed quiet because he’d seen that the girl next to him needed the room to speak.

Halfway through the lesson, the headteacher knocked and leaned in as if the door were a curtain and this was a stage. Mr. Barnes always had the air of a man stepping onto a platform to announce an arrival. He had tried to retire three times and failed all three, and there was rumor that the school would end before he did. The way children continued to believe in him and also did not believe in anything else, that was something.

“Ah! The Bard’s emissaries,” he boomed, then lowered his voice when he saw the plan on the board. “Miss Flint, could you quickly pop into the staffroom at break?”

“Certainly,” she said. He gave a small bow to the fish tank before he left, because for all his bluster he was fundamentally a person who took things to heart.

At break, she left the room in Safia’s charge with a warning about the fish. “Nobody taps on the glass,” she said, and then saw three hands drop, guilty. “And if Gal starts to act like he’s running the place, remind him who pays the water bill. Sit. And absolutely do not set anything on—”

“Fire, Miss,” they chorused, gleeful. “We wouldn’t.”

The staffroom was in that state between a war and a potluck. Coffee, biscuits, papers. Two flyers stuck on the noticeboard: one for yoga, one for CPR training. Somebody had drawn a moustache on the CPR dummy in the photograph. Mr. Shaw was bent over his phone, a smear of porridge on his tie like he’d been kissed by breakfast.

“I saw you at the Mariner on Friday,” he said when he looked up. “You didn’t say you were performing. You were marvelous.”

“I was not,” she said, too quick, and then she wanted to laugh at herself. “But thank you.”

“You did this… something with your voice. That song, what was it?”

“Traditional,” she said. “I don’t know the title. My mum used to sing versions of it when I was small. I think it’s Irish. Or Welsh. Or it just pretends to be everything.”

Mr. Barnes appeared with a plate of two custard creams, which he presented to her as if awarding a medal. “Hannah,” he said, “you’re avoiding the subject as usual.”

“Oh, are we having an intervention?” She took the biscuits. She felt absurdly seen. “Is this about my addiction to chalk, because—”

“It’s about your singing,” he said, softening. “You’re an English teacher pretending to be only an English teacher. Meanwhile, half the town have recorded you on their phones. Do something with it.”

“What would I do?”

“Apply,” Mr. Shaw said. “Britain’s Got Talent. You think we don’t have Wi-Fi in this school? I’ve seen the adverts. I’ve seen you sing. You could. Couldn’t she?”

In the corner, Ms. Davis from Maths looked up from marking and made a face like she’d bit into a lemon and liked it. “I haven’t got telly since 2004. But I’d watch if you were on, Hannah.”

“I don’t want to be one of those teachers who goes on telly and the kids find it and they clip it and slow it down and make it into a meme where I look like a chicken.”

“That will happen no matter what you do,” Mr. Barnes said kindly. “You can either become a chicken on a big stage, or a chicken on a small one.”

“I hate you all,” she said, and bit the biscuit. She wasn’t really upset. The thought of it loosened something. The thought terrified her, made her heart full with panic as if someone had plugged her into the shore power for a ferry. “I don’t know. I have marking. And parents’ evening. And the fish.”

“The fish will rally,” Mr. Shaw said. “We’ll feed them.”

“Not you,” she told him, but there was no bite in it. Her phone buzzed in her pocket—a reminder to drink water, because she had to trick herself into kindness. She sipped his coffee instead, which was a mistake. “Good grief, how do you drink this? It’s like someone brewed a campfire.”

“That’s because the kettle is older than the school,” Ms. Davis muttered.

She thought about it all day, moving around the edges of herself. It wasn’t that she’d never wanted something for herself. She had. She was just good at wanting quietly, in rooms where nobody else could get hurt. Once, years ago, she’d saved up to go to London to see a show and then given the tickets away, because a parent called her the day before and said they couldn’t afford to get their son to the college interview that might change everything, and it turned out the train ticket and her show tickets were close enough, and she’d sat at home and eaten all the strawberries in one go and listened to the whole show on cast recording while she did laundry and told herself it was fine. It had been fine. But it had also not been fine. Both.

At the end of the day, she wrote “Homework: Three paragraphs on ambition in Macbeth” on the board, and put a smiley face with vampire teeth, for reasons known only to her marker. The class groaned like a choir performed by furniture. Out in the corridor, a boy’s voice cracked like a plank splitting.

“Would you apply?” Safia asked her, on her way out, one hand on the doorframe as if anchoring herself. “For that show?”

“I might,” Hannah said, as if answering about a dish she might cook, or a jumper she might try on. “Should I?”

Safia nodded in a very adult way for fourteen. “I think you should do stuff when it scares you. Unless it’s like getting in a stranger’s van. But the other stuff. The mind stuff.”

“Thanks for that detailed moral framework,” Hannah said, smiling. “No vans. Noted.”

When the last child had clattered away, she watered the plants, she fed the fish. Gal performed his small drama again, shimmying, flaring his little tail, lunging toward his own reflection in the glass, then at a bewildered danio who darted off, stripes flashing like a coded message.

“You’ll get yourself worked up,” she told him. “And then what? You’ll jump out onto the carpet and blame me.”

She stood a long moment, hands on the back of a chair, the muscles in her shoulders talking to her. It was as if someone else, years ago, had made a decision about her and she’d been living it ever since; teaching had saved her in so many small ways she didn’t know how to count them. But there was something else she had never admitted, not to her mother, not even to herself on bad days. She missed singing the way some people missed summer when it was winter—an ache that made winter, paradoxically, sharper and more ferocious. Even singing in a corner of a pub with the smell of chips and the stick of beer on the floor had been a kind of sanctuary.

When she got home, Tamsin’s cat was on her doorstep again, a smooth black shape with a bell that never made a sound. Tamsin’s cat did not know she wasn’t Hannah’s cat. She knew that a human lived here who would produce a saucer of milk or a piece of chicken at odd, inconvenient hours. Hannah stiffened herself. “No,” she told the cat. “We have had the talk.”

The cat looked wounded and sauntered off, tail like a question mark. The hall smelled faintly of paint because her neighbour upstairs was forever “doing up” something. She had once knocked and asked what he was doing and he’d told her it was “soundproofing,” which made her wonder what he had previously done that had made so much sound. She had received no further details and tried hard not to need any.

Her mum phoned while she was cooking. She put her on speaker and stirred onions until they were transparent. June Flint had the voice of a woman who had been heard once and wanted to be heard again forever, but kindly, the way an old radio station’s voice can be kind. June had worked in the library until it closed, then at the petrol station until they built a self-serve, and now she worked in a charity shop on the High Street two days a week, and knew most of the town’s gossip without trying for it.

“You at home?” June said. “Or are you out being a night hawk?”

“I am cooking linguine,” Hannah said. “And if I call the dish that, it feels fancier than this thing with onions and a carrot and anxiety.”

“Linguine is always linguistic,” June said, happy. “Guess who came into the shop today.”

“Margaret who thinks the Council is a conspiracy?”

“No, that’s Wednesdays. Today, that man who runs the pier café. He said you made them all cry last Friday. And Janet brought a cake she’d made from scratch, and he said they opened the back doors and let the sea join in. He said you made the room feel like it was a church.”

“That sounds like it violates several health codes,” Hannah said, but she felt the words punch her, gently, in the sternum. “You were always good at getting people to exaggerate.”

“I never exaggerate,” June said, in the tone of someone who exaggerates for a living. “You were exceptional. I wish your father had—well, never mind. I wish he had been the sort of man who liked to hear things that were beautiful.”

“Let’s not,” Hannah said, softly. She did not often say his name. It was like someone had folded it into a paper airplane and thrown it out to sea, and sometimes, on stormy days, felt like it might blow back in.

“Okay,” June said, pivoting. “But Hannah. Have you thought of applying? For that show. I don’t know if it’s on the telly or on the computer these days. Britain’s, you know, talent. You have talent.”

She laughed, but quietly, like somebody told a joke at a funeral. “Everybody in town has this conspiracy. I am being pushed. Is there a newsletter?”

“It’s called we want you to be happy,” June said, and the way she said it made the room colder and warmer at once. Hannah turned the heat down under the saucepan, and rubbed her temple. The cat, which had circled back, screamed at her window as if in sympathy.

“Stop it,” she told the cat. “I can’t be bullied by mammals.”

After dinner, she sat on the floor with her laptop and watched videos. Endless, slick, ridiculous, gorgeous videos of people doing things that made the hair on her arms stand up: tap dancing, a violin that sounded like a person singing with their whole chest, a child standing there small as a biscuit and suddenly sounding like an avalanche. She watched the judges. The sighs. The stage lights that looked like the inside of an eyelid when you closed your eyes too quick. The big gold confetti moment, that blast of manufactured joy that nevertheless looked, at the end of it, oddly real. She watched and felt every hamstring in her body tighten. The very idea of stepping in front of all that and offering herself.

She registered on the site. There was a form. Of course there was a form. Name, age, occupation, location. A space to write about herself. She wrote: I teach English to the best and most terrifying people in Dover. I sing when they’re not looking. She erased it. She wrote: I grew up on the cliff side of town. My mum sings in the kitchen and the gulls are drunk on the bins by the bus stop and none of it has ever stopped me wanting to make a noise that doesn’t go away. She erased it.

Rubbish. All of it too earnest or too odd. She typed: Teacher. Dover. Hannah Flint. Off we go. And clicked save before she could decide it was wrong.

It wanted a video. Of course it did. She stood up, because sitting down, somehow, felt too serious. She set her phone up against a pile of books. The phone slid. She propped it with a mug. The mug held. She opened the window to let air in and Dover came in whole, car by car, shout by shout, the key noise of the town like someone rattling a tin of screws forever. She shut the window again. She took it seriously then: put the phone on airplane mode, ran her hands through her hair like that would fix hair. It didn’t.

“Hello,” she told the camera. “I’m Hannah from Dover, I’m an English teacher, and I would like to sing for you.” It sounded ridiculous as soon as she said it, her own voice sliding away from her like a thing let go. She stopped the recording. She paced. She pressed record again and didn’t say anything this time, just stood there, air-doing the piano introduction, then the song came as if she were hearing it through a wall. She sang it as if somebody needed it right now.

What she had always loved were the songs that sounded like sea shanties even when they weren’t; songs that had come, unhurried, through generations and wind and small kitchens with roller blinds, and only got more themselves as they went. She sang the one she’d sung at the Mariner. She stood in the small light of her lamp and lifted the corners of the words and the room did what rooms do when they were given something to respond to—it waited.

Halfway through, the cat leapt into frame and landed with a disgraceful noise. Hannah soldiered on, because what else. When she finished, she had to laugh. The cat blinked as if having accomplished something important. “A duet,” Hannah whispered, breath streaked with relief. The phone stopped recording a second later. She watched herself back once, not because she liked it—she always looked like she was trying not to look like she was looking at anything—but because she needed to make sure the sound was bearable and that the cat had not knocked the phone flat.

There was a tremor in her jaw she hadn’t known about. She hated that. She loved that. It meant she was paying attention. She uploaded.

The site bar crept along like a snail with a heavy backpack. She made tea and gave the fish a little midnight snack and wiped the kitchen counters like an apology for all the seconds that had passed without her noticing. When the bar turned green and the page declared, cheerily, Thank you! one of her hands was actually shaking, which was a cliché, which she hated, which she forgave.

She dreamed about it that night, in the ridiculous, television-sized way of it: confetti in her hair, her mother sitting in the front row and clapping with a nervousness that made the clapping look like a heartbeat. Mr. Barnes wearing a tie as if it were a flag. The judges vast and frightening like monuments, and the stage smelling of dust and hot electricity. She woke up and laughed in the dark. She went to the bathroom, drank water, stood at the window looking out at the part of Dover that always slept and the part that never did. The ferry horns gave off a mournful shape of sound that seemed to slow her breathing.

The email came three days later. It wasn’t dramatic; there was no trumpet. It was subject-lined in the modern, airy fashion: Next steps: Your Britain’s Got Talent application. It sat there in her inbox like something that might burst or be a dud, and for a long moment she didn’t open it. She walked around her living room with her hands on her hips like somebody hunting for scissors. She sat. She stood. She opened it.

We loved your video, it said. Come to the audition in London. It gave a date. It gave a time. She made a noise that would have, had her door been open, sent cats from three streets over sprinting to her. She laughed to herself with her hand over her mouth, as if there was anyone to hear. She sat down very carefully. She texted one person, and that person was her mother.

Audition, it read. London. It’s happening.

Within seconds, June rang. “I knew it,” her mother said, triumphant and breathless. “Hannah. Oh my heart. Oh my girl. You’ll wear that dress, won’t you. The green one.”

“I’ll wear whatever on the day is clean and doesn’t make me look like a lampshade,” Hannah said, crying and not minding that she was crying. She was quiet about it, so as not to frighten the joy away. “I haven’t told the school yet.”

“The school will throw a parade,” June said. “And I will wave at it from exactly this sofa and then attend with a banner. Do you want me to come to London with you?”

She thought about her mother in that big, busy building with all the noise and waiting and vending machines and never enough seats, about the way June’s knee had started to tell its own long weather. “Maybe not,” she said, love nudging at her throat. “I think I’ll go alone. That way if I fall over with nerves, there will be nobody there to see.”

“Oh, you,” June said softly. “There’ll be thousands to see. And not one of them will mind, if they’re your people. I’m proud of you.”

That day at school, news travelled through the teachers’ wing like steam. She didn’t say it loud; she told Mr. Barnes in his office and he came up out of his chair like a spring, then he told Mr. Shaw in the corridor and Mr. Shaw actually clapped like a seal and called out across the stairwell, and then Ms. Davis stormed into the shared planning space and demanded to know why she had to hear about these things third hand, and then at break there was a cake, because if there was one thing schools could do still, it was a cake, even if it was marked “Congratulations Hannnah” with an extra n that she immediately grew weirdly fond of.

The students smelled news within a lesson. Some of them had already found a clip of her online from the Mariner; one had set it to a filter that gave her rabbit ears. She pretended to be outraged. She wasn’t outraged. She had never felt more seen by people she hadn’t been trying to be seen by.

“Miss,” Noah said, the second his bag touched his desk. “Miss. Miss. If you win, are you going to leave us?”

“Am I going to leave you if I win fame, fortune, and a probable hovercraft?” she said, deadpan. “How dare you ask me such things in this house. We only talk about Macbeth in this house.”

“Seriously,” Safia said. “Are you going to forget us when you’re famous? Big Headline: Dover Teacher Abandons Children For Glitter.”

“I could never abandon glitter,” Hannah said. Then she softened. “I’m not going to forget anybody. I’m going to go and sing and then I’m going to come back and mark your homework and tell you to stop tapping your pens.”

They both grinned at that. It anchored them all.

Two days before the audition, after school, she stood in the music room where Mr. Sands, who was a closed door pretending to be open, let her in to practice. It was odd being in there; she felt like she was wearing someone else’s shirt, the collar too wide and the cuffs dipping over her hands. The room smelled of polish and old pianos and the particular tang of teenage nerves that had been left behind like a vapor. She warmed up, then sang the song twice through in a voice that felt both like her own and remote, like a letter she recognized but couldn’t place.

Mr. Sands listened once through a split of his door like a butler. “You know,” he said finally, “you have the timing of a person who knows how to be quiet, which is rarer than most think.”

“Is that good?”

“It is when you choose when to break it. Break it exactly then.” He marked the bar in the air with a pencil, and she felt, for the first time, the proper shape of the song under her feet, the way some singers talk about it, not like stepping onto a stage, but like stepping onto a boat that had already decided where it would take you. She thanked him and he went, because he was good at going.

On the way home she bought a green dress in a shop none of the students went to, because it was where people their age went to die of boredom. The dress was not the green her mother meant; it was paler and softer, a green you might find buried in the color of a bottle left too long in the sea. She folded it into her bag as if it might speak too loud if she carried it openly.

At home, Gal was in a mood. She’d come to recognize them. The other fish gave him room the way the rest of the world gives room to a small man with a loud voice on public transport—not fear, just a gentle sliding away. He did his reflection routine three times, then broke off suddenly as if offended by how good he looked. She tap-tapped the glass once with her nail and he flared at her, offended.

“Right,” she said. “We’re all on our very best behavior, then. Good.”

She barely slept the night before London. When she did, she dreamed she was in front of the judges and instead of singing she could only recite the Year 9 reading list, “Of Mice and Men” coming out in a high, trembling soprano, “An Inspector Calls” in a weeping whisper, and the audience, bless them, smiled politely as if this were what they had paid for and weren’t quite sure why.

She woke in the grey, the morning not yet committed to being what it was. She made toast and ate half of it and left the other half for the cat who did not belong to her, who appeared as if conjured, sniffed the toast as if insulted, and walked off with great energy. She put on the dress. She looked at herself in the mirror and saw someone who had forgotten how to comb properly and remembered, at the last second, how to stand. She rolled her shoulders. She picked up her bag.

On the train, she sat in one of those seats with a little table, and across from her a man hid inside a newspaper as if war might break out and he needed to be there first. Two teenage girls slid into the seats beside her, chewing something that smelled like watermelon and chemicals, talking at the same time as if their words would collide and that was fine. One of them glanced at Hannah’s hair, at her dress, at the way she kept her hands on her knees like she needed to keep her knees from floating away, and said, kindly, “Are you having a day?”

“A small one,” Hannah said.

“You’ve got this,” the girl said, as if seeing not a day but the whole of a life through the window. She went back to telling her friend about a cat in a video that had jumped onto a man’s head, and the laughter of the two of them together felt like a protection spell. Hannah breathed. The train went into a tunnel and came out the other side, and the world had a different shade of green.

London was so many people it felt like a mistake. She followed signs that did not seem to have anything to do with her, and then they did. She collected a badge. She was called a “contestant” by someone with a clipboard, which made her want to flee into a hedge. She sat with other people who were good at other things: a group in matching tracksuits whose bodies looked as if they might be able to flip without warning, a woman with a dog that had an expression of profound philosophical interest, a man with a violin case that he touched with the care of a newborn’s head.

She did not talk to anyone for a while. She held her cup of water and watched a television in the corner show people doing what they had come here to do. Her name was called. It wasn’t her name at first. It was a number on a list, and then it was her name. Hannah Flint. She stood up and she walked along the corridor where the carpet changed from blue to black as if the building itself knew she was going through something. A woman with a headset smiled at her and performed the same smile she had performed for a hundred players today, and it didn’t matter—it worked on her anyway. The stage door was a mouth. The stage itself, when she was finally stood on it, was a town square. The lights were a weather all their own.

She saw the judges, their collective familiarity doing that trick where it felt as if you knew them, deeply, because you knew the shape of their eyebrows when they heard something they did not expect. She saw beyond them, the shadowed arms of the audience, the black glittering mass of it, the heartbeat of a thousand strangers. It could break you, she thought suddenly, and then: I am not asking it to.

They asked her questions. The usual. She answered the usual. Teacher, yes. Dover, yes. An English teacher. You teach Macbeth? A laugh broke out, one of the judges making a joke about a curse and she smiled in the right places. She held the microphone in both hands. She had practiced standing like a person who knew what to do with their arms. She did not yet know. That was okay, she told herself. That was okay.

“Off you go,” one of them said kindly, as if letting her out into a garden.

She nodded once. She did not look back. Somewhere in the building, somebody dropped something heavy. The stage had its own gravity. She started the song.

That first line went up into the rafters and came back down and hit her in the chest. She nearly laughed at the oddness of it, how her own voice could feel like a boomerang. But then the second line found its feet. The third line knew exactly where to set its cup down. By the third verse, if you could call them verses, she had stopped seeing anything but what was just ahead of her—the next word, and the word after, and the little lift into the vowel there that Mr. Sands had described with his pencil in the air. She did the thing he had told her: she broke the quiet exactly then and then found it again and people in the audience did that involuntary thing, the small sound that you can’t repress when someone meets you where you live.

When she finished, there was a pause that was either horror or grace. Then the room came back on, light and hot, in relief. She smiled because that’s what you do when you can’t think of whether to smile or cry. Someone stood up in the judges’ row. Someone else put their hand over their mouth the way she had done in her living room. She heard someone on the edge of the stage say “Yes” in a whisper, just to themselves. The applause came in waves, and the first wave carried her toward shore and the second wave dunked her and the third wave handed her back, laughing, to herself.

The judges spoke. They were kind. They were not all kind in the same way. One compared her voice to “a thing that knows the difference between a funeral and a hurricane.” Another said she’d never heard a teacher like that before, which was a nice way of saying teachers were held in a particular box, and she had opened the lid. There was a joke about the fish when she mentioned the tank in her classroom. It turned into an odd, wide conversation about empathy and small ecosystems and children learning to be human. She forgot almost immediately exactly what she had said because her body was doing that thing bodies do when adrenaline is both a gift and a curse.

They gave her four yeses. It was the kind of sentence she had heard on television a hundred times and not felt, and now it pinned her to herself kindly. She felt very plainly that she would go back to Dover and teach again next week, and also that she had stepped into a place in her own voice that she could not step back out of.

When she got back on the train, her phone filled with texts and messages and the quick bright burst of a new reality. She read some. She put the phone face-down when it was too much. Across from her, a boy played on his handheld console and made a face like thunder and his dad said gently, “No melting, mate,” and the boy said, “I’m not melting,” with pride, and did the small breathing trick his dad showed him. Hannah learned the trick simply by being there. She did it too, and smiled out the window at the grey coming on.

In the classroom the next day, the fish were fine. Gal, for once, seemed contrite. She fed them. The students filed in with the good gossip eyes, and she let them gossip for a bit because they were children and she had become a kind of news. Later they read a poem by Heaney about feeling the weight of what you are good at and also the weight of not doing it. They didn’t relish Heaney like she did, but they saw a line that was theirs, and marked it.

At lunchtime, Mr. Barnes called a meeting in the hall and announced her audition success like the unveiling of a satellite. There were photos. She hated it; she loved it. On her way back to her room, she saw the science lab door ajar and Mr. Shaw hunched over a tank twice the size of hers. He was doing triage on a snail who had crawled upside down for too long and looked exhausted by it.

“This is my life now,” he said, without self-pity. “Give me a day at sea and six non-moronic teenagers any time.”

“I can offer you fifteen adolescents and a morally complex guppy,” she said.

He looked up. “He does look… what’s the word?”

“Peeved.”

“Aggrieved.”

“Angry,” she said, and heard how it sounded in her own mouth: angry guppy. A stupid, comic phrase to say out loud in a day that felt like it deserved better. She laughed at herself for laughing. “He is, though. I swear he holds grudges.”

“They say fish forget in five seconds,” Mr. Shaw said, then leaned down to whisper to the snail as if it could hear him and it mattered. “I don’t believe them.”

On Friday she went back to the Mariner because she had promised herself she would not stop doing the small versions of the thing just because she had done a big version. The bar was warmer than London and smelled strongly of the potato in chips, and the room didn’t care about judges or the right cut of a dress. Maggie, who ran the place, wiped her hands on a towel and hugged her long and hard. “Only rules still apply,” she said, eyes shocking with brightness. “No singing ‘Wonderwall’. No singing, ‘Hallelujah’ unless you are Leonard Cohen brought back. One free drink if you mention Dover at least once.”

“I’ll mention Dover three times like Beetlejuice,” Hannah said, and Maggie nodded solemnly like that made mystical sense.

The first song went well, which is to say it felt like throwing a ball to a friend a small distance away on a day when your feet kept on solid earth. She didn’t look at people’s faces. She looked just above them, at the framed photo of the cliffs. The second song went better, like a ball that knew its own arc. In the gap between one and two she saw a man at the bar point at his phone and mouth to his mate, That’s her, and then look at her like she might not be and then like she was real anyway.

Somewhere near the top of the weekend, she got an email that said Please do not share any program details (it was all capitals and felt like being told to keep someone’s eyes safe). She didn’t, because even if she had been tempted, she had never been a person who could keep up with one secret and a life at the same time. Still, things moved under the surface. She got a call from a person with a voice like a very confident robot who said words like schedule, risk assessment, wardrobe. She learned she would come back soon, that there were further rounds, that maybe, if she didn’t drop the ball and the ball didn’t suddenly become, say, a cat, she could be on the telly proper.

Between hanging up and making another cup of tea, she felt that odd, split feeling people in old stories must have felt when a ship was due and you couldn’t see it yet, just a darker line on the horizon.

Monday came and went, and so did Tuesday, and the fish did small fish things that felt important to them, and the children did small human things that felt important to her, and late one afternoon, when the sun made a rectangle on her classrooms carpet like a stage she would never step on, because floors were floors and you could not be asked to be a bigger giant than you were, Safia stood by the fish with a frown.

“He’s giving me drama,” she said, meaning Gal, who had puffed himself up to twice his arrogance.

“He gives everyone drama,” Hannah said. “He’s a fish with an ego. We forgive him the way we forgive each other.”

“If he nips my finger I’m telling my mum,” Safia said, delighted to have something silly to say in a week of serious things. She did not put a finger in the tank. Nobody did. The tank hummed its patient hum, the sort of noise that keeps you in this world when your mind tries to go somewhere else.

Hannah tidied, set the chairs on top of the desks to make the cleaners love her, and turned out the light. In the part-shadow, the fish glowed in their separate way. She stood a while longer, listening to what a room listened to after everyone had left it. Then she went home, walking the long way, past the place where the road gave way to the path to the cliff. The wind picked at her hair, and she let it.

At home, she opened the window. The cat arrived within minutes, not surprised to find herself welcome in a house whose owner kept saying no. She placed a saucer on the floor because habits are louder than rules. On the telly, people were also singing. It looked smaller when it wasn’t your stage. It looked like something anyone could do, which was the program’s great trick and also what made it tender.

She turned it off. She drank her tea. She smiled at the darkness gathering like it always had, no matter what theatrics any of them were doing at the other end of the line. She tucked herself into bed and, for once, fell like a dropped coin into sleep. Outside, the sea went on, not caring if she had said “Yes” or if anyone had said it back. It kept on doing what it did. She took comfort in that.

In the morning, the first thing she did—before even making tea—was feed the fish. Gal came up as if ready to negotiate a treaty and then, last second, darted away from a mirrored ghost of himself. Even fish, she thought, had versions of themselves they were frightened of. She tapped the glass very gently, and it made a sound like a small bell. Gal came back, greedy, alive, certain as anything of his small kingdom.

“Don’t get ideas,” she told him. “You and me both.” She dropped a pinch of flake in and he snapped it like a secret. She laughed, at herself, at him, at the week, at the thing she had set in motion without knowing exactly where it would take her.

That afternoon, between helping a boy write a sentence with fewer commas and convincing a girl that the best way to show she was smart was not always to talk loudly, she got another email. Not hugs this time. Not London. Not schedules. Just a line that made her heart go sideways before it steadied. A change in the shape of what was next.

We’re making some adjustments to the live shows, it said. Unlikely, but possible, that due to a situation beyond our control, you may be moved forward if a slot opens. We appreciate your flexibility.

She read it twice. She did not know exactly what it meant. She did know what it felt like, to be told that she might be shoved into a place she wasn’t expecting to be yet. She stood in the doorway of her classroom and watched her students pack their bags and shout again and run for their buses, and thought: whatever happens, happens to the part of me that can breathe on a stage, not the part that knows what Noah needs when he’s trying not to be seen.

On her way out, she said to Gal, “Big changes,” and he flared as if in agreement. She rolled her eyes at herself. She turned off the light, and the glow in the tank went from gold to black and back again as the small engine kept on. Filtering, cleansing, making a small world make sense. She left the room and shut the door on that private weather, holding the banister like a steadying hand as she went down into the evening that waited for her, down in the hall, beyond the door, into Dover, walking squarely into whatever wind there was.Wednesday began with a siren that wasn’t a siren, just the kettle remembering how to shout. Outside, the seafront was still trying to decide whether to be blue or grey, and the gulls were in their morning parliament, grey-suited and outrageously confident. Hannah poured the water and watched tea happen the way weather happens—quietly and then all at once. The email from the night before might as well have been taped to the inside of her skull. Adjustments. Slot opens. Flexibility appreciated. She’d read it, rolled it around on her tongue as if it were a sweet with a bitter centre, and then she’d slept anyway, because sleep was one of the few things she could still do without permission. Now the day stood there, new and ordinary, and she was supposed to be both.

She arrived early at school to mark three essays before anyone else put their noise in the corridor. In the tank, Gal was arranging the morning in the precise, imperfect way he preferred. He chased a tetra half-heartedly, then went to survey his own reflection and quivered in a way that would have been comic if it didn’t look so much like an argument with the self. “All right,” she told him, one hand on the glass, performing the ritual of greeting like it mattered. “I understand. I’m also frighteningly good-looking and that is my burden.” He angled, flared, darted. When she sprinkled the flakes he shot up through them as if trying to catch weather.

By the second bell the corridor was tinny with laughter, and she was already braced for Noah to ask a question that sounded like a philosophy minor had got lost in an English classroom. He didn’t disappoint. “Miss,” he appeared at her elbow, hair doing something architectural, a smear of something on his sleeve that better not be jam. “If ambition wrecks Macbeth, and if ambition also gets you a life, where’s the line? Because you always tell us there’s a line. That’s like your whole thing.”

“My whole thing,” she said, “is ‘use your commas sparingly’ and ‘wash your hands after the loo.’ And then, maybe, then, ambition. The line is where it stops belonging to you and starts belonging to hurting other people.”

“That’s not a line,” he objected, but he smiled when he said it. He saw the fish the way he saw everything, in glances and leaps. “Gal looks a bit weird.”

“He looks like himself,” she said. “Which is exhausting enough.”

Mid-morning, the headteacher’s voice rose over the staffroom like a trumpet done quietly. Mr. Barnes had a way of delivering news that made it feel like you were all in the same boat, even if the boat was sinking. “Hannah,” he said when she stepped in, having been paged over the dodgy speaker system that cut out on the word “urgent” and replaced it with a noise like a door being kicked. “How are your nerves?”

“Serviceable,” she said. “We talking general or specific?”

“Specific. You’ve had something from the programme?”

She nodded, holding out her phone so he could see the email, because she had not yet learned how to pretend she did not want a witness to everything. Mr. Shaw leaned over Mr. Barnes’ shoulder, porridge, incredibly, already redeemed into a fresh tie, like a man who believed in second breakfasts.

“They’re asking if you can shift,” Mr. Barnes said, reading. “Move up if someone drops, so to speak. Could happen, might not happen. And if it happens, it sounds like very short notice, doesn’t it. Of course it does.”

“What day is short notice in television?” Mr. Shaw said, hauling a chair over to sit and fully commit to the conversation. “They could call you while you’re on the loo and expect you to belt it out over the hand dryer.”

“I hate this image,” Ms. Davis said from the corner without looking up. “Also, I’ve thought about it and we will have to organise cover. Look at this timetable.” She slid Hannah’s key lessons across the table like a deck of cards she could read. “Year 11 mock feedback Friday. Parents’ evening Thursday.”

“I can move parents’ evening,” Mr. Barnes said, like a magician disappointed nobody appreciated the trick. “I’ll call it a climate event. We’ll evacuate them into next week. It’s fine.”

“It isn't,” Hannah said, and heard the smallness in her own voice and immediately wanted to make it more generous. “But thank you. I’m worried about leaving them mid-battle. Macbeth’s in the witches.”

“They’ll still be in the witches when you get back,” Mr. Shaw said. “The witches are patient. You’re allowed to go and do something that is for you. We will mind your children. We will not feed Gal. I cannot stress this enough.”

“You fed them once,” she said. “They still talk about it.”

He winced. “I misread the tub. In my defence, the tub was very mislabeled.”

“Not at all,” Ms. Davis said, because she couldn’t resist. “It said fish food.”

They were ridiculous and they were a family of sorts. She felt the warm swill of being protected and wanted to resist it because protection sometimes came with obligations she couldn’t pay back. Mr. Barnes landed the plane, as he did. “If they call,” he said, “we’ll arrange cover. You’ll go. We’ll be proud and grumble and send you texts. You will come back. I’ve been here long enough to know how this works.”

She kept her phone face down during Period 3 in case the call made her heart do something visible. Period 4 it vibrated anyway and she let the students get on with their writing while she stepped into the corridor and looked at the number as if she might be able to change it by will. Unknown. Of course. A woman with a pleasant, brisk voice introduced herself and told Hannah, delightfully, that everything was either fine or very much not fine.

“So, we’ve had a… situation,” the woman said, with the bright glide of someone who wore a lanyard shaped like a shield. “A group can’t perform due to a travel issue. We are shuffling. There is a possibility—and I stress possibility—you might go in their place. It would be this Sunday. That gives you…” Hannah heard tapping and imagined a schedule falling down a set of stairs. “It gives you three days. We would want you Saturday for rehearsal.”

“That’s… yes,” Hannah said, and then because she had taught herself to be specific in a crisis, added, “I am a teacher. I have parents’ evening Thursday and mocks Friday. I can rehearse on Saturday. I can be in London Sunday. I will be underprepared Thursday and somehow more prepared Sunday.”

“Brilliant,” the woman said, genuinely sounding like it was. “We’ll have our musical director call you to talk about arrangements. The folk piece you did—we loved it, the EP loved it—but the live show we might want to add texture. Something that grows. Strings, maybe a bodhrán, something that is not dreadful. We don’t do dreadful. I’ll email. Oh, and media. We’ll manage your press. Don’t announce. Not yet.”

“Not announcing is my strongest skill,” Hannah said, then hung up and stood very still in the corridor and listened to the heavy breathing of the building—the pipes, the ancient radiators, the stampede of Year 8s somewhere above. Her pulse felt like the sea at spring tide. She wanted to sit down but there was nowhere to sit that didn’t look like a child had once cried there.

In her classroom, the students had performed a miracle. They had written quietly for two whole minutes while she was gone because she had asked them to. Safia looked up when she came in and tilted her head. “You okay, Miss?”

“I am very okay,” she said, and meant it and didn’t. “I am a person who will need to drink water and breathe, which are both free, and then I will be okay. Commas. Who needs me with commas?”

That afternoon, while the others went to the car park to argue about whose mother was worse, she found Mr. Sands in the music room and told him what she could tell. He nodded like an old metronome. “You’ll want to pick something you can lean on if the floor moves,” he said. “The floor will move. It won’t be the end of the world; it’ll feel like it is. Whatever you pick, it should have a hinge. Somewhere you can rest a second inside it and then open it and go through.”

He had a list. Of course he had a list. He was the kind of man who had a list on onion-skin paper. They tried two songs in the dim gold of the room, windows fogged with the ghosts of trumpet lessons. One was too cheerful; it tasted like seaside rock. The other had something in it like salt. She sang, then stopped, then sang again, and the second time, halfway through, there was that hinge he’d promised. She stepped through it and found herself on the other side, in air clearer than she’d had any right to expect. When she was done, he made a small noise like somebody had placed a chess piece exactly where it had always wanted to be. “That one,” he said. “You can make the room do what you ask with that one.”

On the way home she walked past the charity shop on the High Street and stared at the jumble in the window until her own reflection arranged itself into someone she recognised. A coat on a hanger looked like a person waiting to be picked up. June had scrawled on a bit of card for their book table: Two for one, unless I know you’re rich. XXX June. The shop was not open, it was never open at the exact moment when you thought “Yes, now,” but she liked the feeling of her mother’s handwriting out there like a flag.

At home, the cat was a small, sleek alarm. It sat on the doorstep, refusing to move with such determination that the world bent around it. “I will not be owned by this relationship,” Hannah told it, and then let it in anyway because she was what she was. She pulled out her phone and called her mother and managed to say it without making it sound like a storm. June took it like any weather. “Right,” she said, “so I’ll set my telly to record and I’ll put cakes in the freezer because you never know who’ll show up, and I’ll tell Margaret she’s not to come to mine on Sunday to talk about the bins unless it’s an emergency, and if it is an emergency she will bring the bins with her because I won’t miss you.”

“You don’t have to watch it live,” Hannah said, trying to be kind and not sure if kindness looked like that. “You can watch in your own time.”

“I would like to be with you in it while it’s happening, thank you very much,” June said, stout as a lighthouse. “You don’t have to be brave for me. Be brave for the girl who loved songs. I’ll mop up after her if she cries.” She said it like a pact. Then, because she was also the sort of mother who knew about knees and weather, she added, “I went up the stairs at the shop today and my left knee told me the truth, which is that it is well past its best and would like to be replaced with something titanium and glamorous. I am telling you this to remind you that bodies are both miracles and liars. Eat a potato.”

“I’m going to London, not the trenches,” Hannah said, but she found herself putting actual butter on a potato later and eating it like a person who believed in fuel.

Thursday she stood for three hours under strip lights while parents told her everything and nothing and she told them that their children were trying and brilliant and complicated and that she was very proud to be in their lives. She meant it down to the marrow. She meant it even about the ones who had made her want to throw a thesaurus out of a window. Noah’s mother wore a coat that made her look like a saffron; she shook Hannah’s hand hard enough to make the skin of her palm ache. “He says you’re good,” she said. “He says you see him. That’ll do me.”

Safia’s father did a strict nod like a folded piece of paper and said, “Please keep her busy. She talks less when she has to read.” Safia rolled her eyes and looked away and then looked back and mouthed, “Thank you,” like a tiny revolution.

It was after the last parent had gone and the custard creams had been beaten into dust that she went back to her classroom to turn off the lamp and found Gal not right. It took her a second. Fish were always doing something that looked like nothing and vice versa. He hovered in the corner like an idea that hadn’t decided whether it would be good. When he flicked, the tails of his fins looked ragged, as if he’d gone through a small, personal storm. The lamp made his colours too clear. She knelt, very gently the way people talk to babies and gods, and watched. He darted. He did not dart as he usually darted. He didn’t posture at himself, which might have had you calling emergency services.

She found Mr. Shaw packing his bag with the look of a man who had not stopped moving since 1999. “My fish,” she said, and he took one look at her and put the bag back down.

“Describe your fish,” he said.

“Ruffled,” she said, aware it wasn’t the science word. “Tired. Like me,” she added, to forestall the joke.

“Could be fin rot,” he said. “Or stress. Or his own personality biting him, which can happen. I’ll look.” He bent to the tank and squinted like he was reading a poem written very small. “He’s frayed. You need to keep the water extra clean. No overfeeding. Bit of aquarium salt if you’ve got it, very small amount. Turn down the light. Pretend you are a spa, not a disco.”

“I’ve never been a disco,” she said, solution and worry fighting like cats behind her ribs. “Will he be okay?”

“He’s a guppy,” he said. “They’re tougher than they look. But they’re not immortal. None of us are. Which is annoying when you’ve got a weekend like yours.” He put a hand on her shoulder, which he did rarely enough that she felt it as a blessing. “Go to London. I’ll check on them Saturday. I promise not to feed them.”

“You will positively not feed them,” she said, because rituals mattered. “And if he’s gone when I come back, I will pretend to handle it and then cry in a cupboard.”

“You can cry in my cupboard,” he said. “It has a chair and a poster of Marie Curie.”

Friday was the kind of day schools specialise in. A fire alarm. A debate in the corridor about whether a bacon sandwich was morally wrong. A girl with a headache the size of France. Hannah stood in the middle of it with her hands open and let it happen and did what you do when you don’t get to control anything: you controlled the controllables. She photocopied. She left a folder for her cover teacher labelled in a way that would make it impossible for anyone to say they didn’t know what to do. She put sticky notes on the fish food. She wrote a silly, stern note and stuck it over the tank: I’m watching you. Be civil. She resisted the urge to sign it “Love, God.”

In the afternoon she got fifteen minutes with Mr. Sands, a piano, and the song that had chosen her. They flipped it inside out. They took bars away and put them back. It felt like turning up the collar of a coat and finding someone else’s name stitched in and deciding to leave it there. He made a face at the phrase they knew had to lift, and she lifted it until the ceiling noticed. When she finished, he didn’t clap. He put his hand flat on the piano as if to steady it. “Don’t let them hurry you,” he said, noting the places where the years had made him kind instead of brittle. “You go in with your own weather.”

Saturday early, she took the train to London with a bag that made her feel like she was moving cottages. She had never been to television rehearsals, but she had read a lot of books and seen enough behind-the-scenes content to walk in as if she could identify a gaffer in the wild. The building they used as a base looked like a very expensive car park. Inside, everything was polished and unfinished at once, wires like vines, walls that were both temporary and permanent, people with headsets moving in the purposeful way people moved when they had been told not to let things go wrong.

There was a room labeled Contestants which made her laugh because she kept forgetting she was one. Inside it, a group of boys were drumming on their thighs, a woman with hair like a bird of paradise was quietly humming scales, and a man with a face your grandparents would trust was oiling his violin bow the way some people pat a horse before they ride it. The dog was there, too, the philosophical one, gazing at a tin bowl as if it contained the secrets of the universe and perhaps it did.

They put her in front of a camera with a young man who asked questions in a voice like a smile. He asked why she taught. He asked why she sang. She answered the same answer two different ways because that’s what the truth looks like when you turn it. The producer with the bright voice from the phone had a body to go with it and a clipboard you could probably have used as shelter in a storm. “We’ll try strings,” she said to Hannah, her pen clicking like a clock. “We have this arrangement we can build from. Our MD is a genius disguised as a person. Don’t panic. If we panic you’ll know because we all start walking faster and you will feel it like a tide.”

They went through it with the band in a half-lit space that made everything feel like dressing up. The first run was too polite. The second found its bones. The third made the hair on her arms stand up like wheat. The MD, who had the face of someone who could hear sketches of Bach in a printer, tapped the stand and said, pleased, “There. Again from there.” The strings lifted like a breath, a drum came in under them with the patience of someone walking alongside someone else who could not walk fast. She held the microphone in both hands because there was nowhere else to put the need, and sang, and for a second she saw Dover behind the blackness of the room. She saw the cliffs and the classroom and her mother’s hands tapping the steering wheel in time when she drove her to primary school, one finger, then another, then the whole hand, with the radio or with the song in her head, whatever was playing that day.

Between the rehearsals, she sat with the drumming boys and talked about nothing that was actually nothing: chips, trainers, the way London air tasted like a coin. One of them said, “You don’t seem scared,” a statement rather than a question, and she laughed without laughing, which was a skill she’d honed. “I am very good at both being scared and holding tea without spilling,” she said. He nodded as if this were an ancient art and was proud to know its name.

Then, because all stories contain a piece you didn’t ask for, her phone buzzed and it was the charity shop, or rather, Dorothy from the charity shop, who did not believe in preambles. “Your mother’s all right,” Dorothy announced. “Before you get in a state. She slipped on a black plastic bag some idiot left on the floor. Sat down hard. I told her she’d done it wrong if she meant to be graceful. Knee’s protesting. We’ve iced it. She will sit for two hours because I told her she would and because she cannot get up without me and that is how I like my friends, occasionally captive. She says not to ring. I am ringing because after two hours she will pretend nothing happened. Don’t come. If you come, I’ll hide you in the racks because Margaret will be here and she’ll only try to adopt you.”

Hannah leaned back against a wall that might have been a set and closed her eyes because sometimes that made the world tilt back into place. “Thank you,” she said. “Tell her I love her, and I will come after, and I will bring something inappropriate from the supermarket and a determination to make her sit with her leg up.”

“I’ll make sure she’s clean for your visit,” Dorothy said grandly, as if June were a spaniel that had rolled in something. “Go and be marvellous. We will do the domestic follies. We are very experienced at it.” She hung up without goodbye in the way of women who remembered when phone calls were expensive.

Hannah stood there another minute and let herself be someone’s daughter very hard, then put the phone away and went back to rehearsal, because there are only so many choices. The stage manager took them through the walk, the stand, the look-left, the breathe. “Find your mark,” he said to each of them in turn, and there was something childlike and holy about it. Find your mark. As if you were always meant to end up exactly there.

She went back to Dover that evening because sleeping in a white hotel where the art was framed abstractly would have made her feel like a person in a brochure, and she needed to be a person in a bed with a cat that wasn’t hers. The train had that end-of-day ache that rides home in other people’s faces. A pair of lads argued about whether gravy on chips was universal truth or a personal failing. A woman in a fluorescent vest slept with her mouth open, shrugged into her nap like armour. The cat was waiting as if it had engineered the timetable. It showed her its entire contempt of the universe and then ate what she put down with the focus of a meditator. She texted Dorothy and received a photo of June with a bag of frozen peas on one knee and a grin that was all schoolgirl, and the caption, in Dorothy’s scrawl: Will live. Very annoyed to be alive. Bring cake.

On Sunday the sea looked like somebody had sanded it. A thin rain had been thrown up and then forgotten. She put on the dress, the one that looked like glass that had learned to be kind. She looked at herself in the mirror and felt poised over the day like a bird over a wave deciding whether to dive. In the kitchen, she wrote a note nobody would see: Feed fish. Breathe. Okay. She left it on the table anyway, like a spell.

The staging area backstage had become a fairground of nerves. They had a run-sheet with everyone’s name in neat columns and everything about it suggested certainty while everything about it was secretly made of decisions. Someone in a suit jogged past in trainers. A woman in a gold jumpsuit muttered about zips. The dog had a small moment with a polystyrene cup and was redirected kindly. When they miked her, the sound tech said, “You’ve got a nice voice,” in the flat tone of someone who meant it and had said it to people who didn’t deserve it, which made it feel like a gift.

Then the bit that wasn’t supposed to happen happened, which is that the big voice came over from somewhere in the sky and said her name earlier than it should have. The act before had been cut short for something that sounded important up close and wouldn’t matter at all tomorrow; the song before hers had been all fireworks and she had to walk out into whatever heat was left. The lighting guy, bless him, didn’t meet her eye, because professionals know when looking at you might break you. The stage manager said calmly, “We’re up,” and touched her elbow exactly once and then let go.

The first line of the song had to be placed on a table without cracking. She thought of Mr. Sands and his hinge and of Gal with his ragged fin, holding himself slightly differently and still himself. She thought of Noah drawing his dragon in the corner of every page, the same dragon, the same corner, because staking a claim on a corner is sometimes all a growing person can do. She thought of her mother’s knee and the way June would tell it off, bromide-filled peas sweating onto a tea towel, more annoyed than defeated. She thought of Dover cutting the sky cleanly, of the part of the sea that belonged to ferries and the part that belonged to quiet thoughts, and she set the first line down.

We could say that the rest took care of itself, but that would be letting the work pretend to be a miracle. She did the work. She lifted where she had to and rested where she could and looked at nobody and everybody. The strings held, and when she leaned they took her weight, and the drum beneath her was careful and then not careful, which was exactly what she needed from anyone right then. Something happened in the second verse that wasn’t planned and didn’t matter except that it mattered to her. She heard a sound from the audience that was too small to be clapping and too big to be a breath, a sound like someone finding their own heart in their pocket by accident, and she smiled without meaning to and a camera somewhere caught it. Later, June would text her that that bit made three separate people in the charity shop cry, and Dorothy would reply, only one of them because of haemorrhoids.

After, you go and stand somewhere and get told that you did it, as if that sentence can hold anything. The judges said words again and some of them landed and some of them floated off with the confetti. She heard someone say “authentic,” which is a dangerous word if you let other people own it. She thought: I am the only one who knows why this was real. She looked down and saw that she had been holding the microphone with both hands again and laughed at herself for not learning any faster. The lights warmed her skin and then stopped. She walked off. Someone hugged her. Someone else missed and hugged a piece of air. The gold on everything looked like the inside of a throat.

There was no confetti because it wasn’t that sort of yes, not yet. There was a different kind of recognition which came from people who had backstage jobs and had seen too much and could tell when a thing had done what it meant to do. A woman with a headset pressed her hand once in a sandwich of hand-and-clipboard and said, “That’s how we do it,” in the way people say “We” when they didn’t lift a finger and also lifted lots of fingers. Hannah wanted to sit down on the floor and drink water forever. Instead she went to the place where the press was and said the three sentences she had learned to say—Teacher. Dover. Love to my students—and then she escaped with dignity that looked a lot like running.

The train back that night was full of people who thought they had seen something and weren’t sure whether to admit it. A man across from her kept trying to catch her eye and then chickening out, which she understood on a spiritual level. Two girls took a selfie and then whispered so loud you could hear the whisper from three seats. She texted Mr. Barnes, Mr. Shaw, Ms. Davis, Mr. Sands. The group chat exploded into gifs that meant “We can’t cope,” and “We coped,” and “Now what.” She texted June and Dorothy and received a photo of an empty plate and a caption: Cake has passed on. Went doing what it loved.

On Monday, the school moved as if nothing had happened and also as if everything had. The children were kind to her in the way children are kind when they decide an adult belongs, which means they mocked her gently and took the mick about her dress and staged a two-minute debate about whether she had eyebrows when they saw her on telly, because makeup. She laughed at them and made them read a sonnet and the world knit itself back together.

At break, she went to check on Gal. Mr. Shaw had left a note, capital letters, a drawing of a fish with a cape. He had done the salt in the right proportions, or close enough, and Gal was not cured but he was not worse. He swam with intent. His fins, still a little torn, moved like flags after a storm: battered but legible. Hannah put her hand to the glass and in some way that did not bear scientific scrutiny, he came to it. It felt like solidarity even if it was just habit. “We’re not going to die of it,” she told him. “Either of us. Not this week.”

That afternoon, as if the world were regularly scheduled and had no room for a subplot, Mr. Barnes rolled assembly in like a circus and made her stand there while the whole school cheered and then pretended not to have done it because public displays of anything are death if you’re fourteen. She said something about trying and failing and trying anyway, and the microphone squealed and she winced and they laughed kindly at her pain. On the back row, Noah pretended to pretend he wasn’t proud, which was a perfect circle of love drawn with a pen that was running out. Safia did a tiny clapping motion, hands just apart, like a bird.

Late in the day, when the building had done its worst and was finally winding down like a radio station, the email came. It did not shout. It did not need to. It said: Next live round scheduled. It said: Rehearsal Thursday. It said: Publicity Tuesday. It said: Please keep all details confidential and be aware of press interest. It said: We were moved by the way you did the quiet. Our director would like you to consider a change to your second verse. It said: Call us.

She called, because you don’t not call a person who holds a small part of your life between two fingers like that. The producer sounded as if she had been not sleeping for a hundred hours and also like she could run a small country on the side. “We want the story,” she said. “The Dover of it, the teacher of it. We want the classroom in the song without it being literal. Think we can do that?”

“I don’t do literal unless I’m labelling fish food,” Hannah said. She thought of Heaney. She thought of the boy on the train with the breathing trick. She thought of her mother’s peas. “We can do that.”

When she left the building, it was already evening, and the light made a long strip on the floor of her room like a rug someone had rolled out toward a door she hadn’t noticed. She put the chairs on the desks. She wiped the board clean of the day’s vocabulary. She paused in the doorway longer than was normal, the way you do when you want someone to say “Don’t go,” and there is nobody to say it because you have made your decisions and the room has its own life to get on with. In the tank, the small engine hummed. In the glass, she saw herself twice and the fish three times and the room infinite. She was a bit of everything: teacher and singer, daughter and person with a cat she wasn’t allowed, woman who would get on a train and go to a place not built for her and stand there anyway.

Outside, Dover lifted its chin to the night. The gulls were already asleep on whatever surfaces they had claimed, the buses were doing their last rounds like stubborn angels, and out past the harbour wall the sea rehearsed the same line it had always rehearsed, with conviction and without applause. She locked the door, took the banister in her hand as if it were a friend, and went down into the evening, the promise of new wind not frightening and not benign, but simply itself, and met it like you meet an old truth.The week opened itself like a map and immediately showed her the fold that always resisted lying flat. Tuesday was branded “publicity” in the email that did not bother with punctuation beyond the bossy, and she had the small, ridiculous urge to iron her day the way you iron a shirt you want a stranger to approve of. Dover decided to behave like a town from a brochure, sky rinsed and gulls distant, as if someone had turned down their volume. The crew arrived in a white van that made the street look abruptly like a scene that had been ordered rather than lived, and Ms. Davis stood in the car park with her arms crossed and her mouth set in the way of a gate. They had permissions and badges and a man with a clipboard who said he loved schools, which Hannah tried not to interpret. They were careful and they were quick and they were wrapped in the smell of coffee and new batteries, and when they walked into 9C they took their hats off in the way that people still do, instinctive, as if classrooms were small churches with posters about safe sex.

They filmed the tank without the children in the room, because Mr. Barnes had said very clearly in a meeting that you do not let a camera see a child whose mother or father has not signed a piece of paper, and you do not even let a camera think about seeing a child, not without a piece of paper that could get God out of trouble. The cameraman—a young woman with a nose ring and a serious, practical plait—knelt like a supplicant and filmed Gal from his good side, which made Hannah laugh quietly because Gal would be unbearable if he knew he had one. He was still frayed but he would not be cowed; he surged toward the lens with the kind of swagger that, scaled up, would get you barred from pubs.

“Hero fish,” the sound man whispered, smiling like a conspirator as he held a fuzzy microphone that looked like a mammal you might whisper your sins into. “What’s his name?”

“Gal,” she said, and when he looked blank she added, “After a knight, but not the shiny one. The one who keeps making the wrong decision and then turns around and tries again.”

“Good man,” the sound man said to the fish, which felt perfectly natural in the context of a day that had agreed to be odd. They filmed her at the board and at the piano that lived in the corner and refused to stay in tune, not singing properly because they made it clear they didn’t want her to empty the cupboard before the party. They filmed her hand underlining a sentence, and when they watched that back on a tiny screen it looked like something gentler than marking, like mending a seam.

She had laid out the exercise books with the appealing audacity of a person who believed that handwriting, properly done, could move mountains. Some of the children watched the incident through the door as they were allowed to pass in pairs on their way to Science, which Mr. Shaw had agreed to because he was in a reckless mood and had already terrorised his Year 10 with Bunsen burners before ten a.m. Safia stood with her head in the doorframe and her hair in a state of opinion, and when the camera turned toward the corridor like a sunflower she ducked in a way that would have shamed an acrobat. Later she reappeared with a great seriousness and said, “Miss, if you are going to be on the telly again, can you make sure your eyebrows are even, because my mum said—” and then stopped, delighted with herself, because she knew very well she was pushing and guessing at the line, and took herself away before anyone else could.

The local paper, which employed a man who wore a tie out of respect for things and who collected the town’s stories the way people used to collect bus tickets, asked for a photograph on the esplanade. Hannah put on a coat that made her look marginally more like a person in charge of her own life and stood by the railings while waves did what they had always done, which was make a nonsense of railings. The photographer kept saying things like “chin down” and “eyes up” and “think of a funny thought” and she tried to oblige by thinking of Mr. Barnes bowing to the fish tank as if to a monarch. A gull swept in and took one look at the tableau and made a noise that could have been derision or blessing. The caption, the photographer promised, would be kind, because his mother liked her mother and this was how you did journalism in a town built like a family.

On the way back from that, she took the long route and stopped in at the charity shop with a paper bag she pretended was an impulse buy and was actually cake. June was sitting behind the till with a knee that was a small weather system, the bag of peas now a legend in a story that had already accrued five versions depending on who told it.

“I was twirling,” June announced as if it would be unkind not to lead with the ridiculous. “I was doing the tango with a bin liner. Dorothy said it was more like the foxtrot with a dishrag. The point is, only my pride bruised, and possibly the bit of me that said I was still seventeen. Give me a slice of whatever you’ve got. I promise not to rate it and then I might rate it anyway.”

They sat at the back on two chairs that had belonged to a church that had moved on and to a wedding that had ended happily if the scratched initials on the underside of the seats could be believed. They ate cake with a kind of full-bellied silence that only people who have known each other a long time can carry off. June watched Hannah with the way she watched her daughter, which was always several emotions at once. Pride came first. Then fear. Then joy. Then a fourth thing that was like the memory of a bridge they had crossed once in rain that had been both a nuisance and a blessing.

“You’ll look after yourself?” June said, because mothers had to ask or else the sky would fold in. “You’ll remember to eat and the bit in the song that feels like you’ll fall off the edge isn’t the edge at all, it’s the bit right before you get the handrail? You’ll remember your own handrail?”

Hannah thought of the hinge, and of the breath she had found inside the song like a place to sit down in a field that had previously offered only standing. She thought of the banister and the way she gripped it every evening as if it were a person with a very steady personality. “I’ll remember,” she said. “And if I forget, I’ve got professional reminders with clipboards who will hustle me back into remembering.”

“They’d better,” June sniffed, and then softened, because hardness did not suit her for long. “When you were small you used to sing to your rubber duck and you’d pretend it didn’t float unless your song told it how. I need to tell you that the duck floats anyway. But it floats better when you do.”

Thursday’s rehearsal brought the part of the process that Hannah hadn’t anticipated would undo her, which was the smallness of the kindness between strangers who were suddenly on the same team. The MD had arranged the invisible classroom into the song without a single literal bell. There was a rasp of bow against string that sounded like chalk finding the right angle. There was a high line that could have been a child deciding to speak. There was a drum so soft it could have been thumbs on a desktop. When she sang into that, the words found a way of carrying their own memory without dragging it around by the hair. She leaned into the hinge and it swung as if the song had been waiting years for somebody to open it.

Between run-throughs, she paced the corridor where other people’s nerves had been left to cool, and she caught sight of herself in a panel of glass that had decided to act as a mirror just for this afternoon. She looked like someone who had told the truth by mistake and been applauded for it, which was the sort of luck you did not rely on. Her phone vibrated like a small creature with a warning, and she made the mistake of looking at it between doors, just long enough to see a message that began, Who does she think she is, and a profile picture of someone whose dog looked very happy. She slid the phone back into her bag with a level of care that did not match the threat and took a breath against the brick wall that smelled faintly of new paint and older anxiety. The MD opened the door a crack and saw it on her face, the thing of being very visible and also very attackable, and he did not say anything deep or supportive. He raised his eyebrows and said, “One more? From the place where it breaks?”

They did it again, from the broken bit, which was how you learned not to fear it, and the breaking place became something else. It became the part of the song that knew her, and she knew it, and when you meet yourself like that on a stage, the part of the audience that has been waiting to meet themselves too will find you where you stand.

Friday, a letter came from the Department of Education that looked official and turned out to be a round-robin about attendance figures and football boots, and a card came from a woman called Maureen with a pen that stuttered across the paper where it hit the raised bit where “With Sympathy” would have been on cards for other occasions. “We watched you,” it said, with a sea of exclamation marks that wanted very much to be polite. “My husband said you had the lungs of an old mining choir. I told him not to be rude and then he cried. We are not from Dover but we came there once on a bus trip in 1997 and had a very bad sandwich which I am obviously not blaming you for.
