I hope you don’t stop.” She pinned it to the noticeboard with the yoga flyer and the CPR moustache and the map for the fire exits, because in a school, all human events end up in one messy constellation anyway.

She had briefly believed that she could keep the piece of herself that liked to be alone with her singing only slightly less alone, that she could learn to stand on the bigger square of light without also being invited to be a person for other people to have opinions about in their kitchens. The online thing pushed back against that quiet fantasy with the inexorable pressure of a tide you hadn’t read on the chart. She did what she always did when she didn’t trust the weather; she sought out sensible people who had never once pulled her into a storm, and she brought them biscuits so they’d be happy telling her the truth.

“You’ll need to not read the comments,” Ms. Davis said, eating a custard cream with the methodical efficiency of somebody reading through the answer booklet and circling B’s. “And you’ll need to fail at not reading them and then not write back to them, which will be a new muscle. If someone rings the school because they are cross that you have a job and also a dream, tell them to ring me. I like the cross. They’re my people. I drain them of their cross and send them into the afternoon with a reminder to do their spellings.”

“Some of them are kind,” Hannah said, because she wanted to admit all the weather when she talked to Davis or else she would be corrected. “Sometimes they say a thing that looks like it could go in a pocket for later. I don’t like to pretend there isn’t good in it.”

“You can carry the good in one pocket,” Ms. Davis allowed. “The other pocket you fill with pebbles, for throwing at the gulls. I’m joking. Don’t throw at the gulls. They know people who will throw back.”

Mr. Barnes came and stood at the doorway with the small pose he did when he wanted a moment without it feeling like a moment. He had a letter in his hand and a glint that could end a war. “We’ve had a complaint,” he began in a tone that said the complaint could go into the bin as politely as into the fire. “Someone’s very concerned that your sudden celebrity might destabilise the already precarious boat of Year 9’s attention spans.”

“Does the someone have a name?” Hannah asked, and when he told her, she nodded, because the name belonged to a person who had reasons, who had lived in a small town for a long time and believed in keeping everyone at the correct altitude. “I’ll speak to her,” she said. “I’ll tell her that all my teaching is still done with chalk on the same boards, and that fame is a word that belongs to other people and not to me. I’ll tell her that no matter what town my face appears in, this is the only room I care to own.”

“You’ll tell her,” he agreed, and folded the letter into a small square that ended up in his pocket as if that were the natural end of all official documents. “And I will tell her that if we don’t allow our own to go and be seen, then we only ever see strangers, and what good is that.”

In the midst of all that, small life kept insisting on being cared for. Noah forgot his homework and turned up with a poem folded into a plane instead, which he launched too soon and then went to fetch as if participation had always been his plan. Safia said “blood will have blood” in a rebuttal about Macbeth with a crispness that could have cut carpet, and then softened and said, “but also sometimes blood will have a nap,” which made the room laugh and then think and then write something better than they would have written without humour. A boy who had practised sullen to the point where it had become an art form asked quietly if he could read his work out, and when he did, his voice wobbled in a way that made another boy who “didn’t do feelings” go still for a full five seconds. Hannah watched the five seconds and then watched them break into adolescence again like a shoal breaking for the light, and she put it in her other pocket, the one she kept for what mattered.

Saturday came round again because days insist on sequence no matter how dramatic you want them to be. She walked to her mother’s with a bag of shopping and half the town stopping her to tell her the details of their viewing habits. She adored and tolerated it with the same reserves. June had her leg up and a book under the cushion and no intention of making this about pain when there was cake to discuss, and by the time Hannah left, Dorothy had turned up with a jar of pickled onions insisting they cured disappointment, which made no sense and also some sense. On the way home, the mariner’s wind caught her and put colour into her face that no makeup on any programme could have faked.

That night the cat was waiting on the windowsill again, bell silent, whiskers organised. Hannah opened the window and let it in and said nothing about boundaries because boundaries were for daylight. The cat did a full perimeter and then settled with the insulted sigh of a creature who had once been worshipped and found the present day wanting. She sat on the floor with her back against the cupboard and her legs out in front of her and let the room feel itself around her. When she sang softly into the quiet—half a verse, a line for luck—it wasn’t for rehearsal or for a camera but to remind her body that it could make a sound and trust it to leave and not be lost.

Sunday felt less like a mountain to climb and more like a hill she already knew, because she had learned the shape of the day now, where the stairs were and where the carpet changed its mind. The backstage smelled of hairspray and the inside of a black coat, and the people with headsets nodded at her in the way you nod at someone in church when you’re not supposed to be greeting but it would be rude not to. She played a game with herself to settle her heart to a manageable architectural tremor; she thought of all the banisters she had put her hands on and thanked each one in turn, the school, the charity shop, the stairs at the Mariner with their carvings, the unforgiving rails at the pier. She thought of the tank and the way the engine hummed like a small, determined animal. She thought of Gal, already perhaps re-growing a whisper of fin, and it steadied her more than it had any right to. It was absurd to be steadied by a fish and it was also exactly right.

The producer caught her by the elbow as she set her foot on the stairs to the stage, and she braced without knowing whether it would be a change or a blessing. “It’s yours,” the woman said, and she said it with the quiet that powerful people put on when they have decided to be careful with you. “If the audience get excited early, don’t let them rush you. If they cough, don’t panic. If the lights feel warmer than last time, it’s because they are. They have moods. We all do. Yours is the weather tonight.”

In London, time behaved like a rubber band, generous and cruel. The first note hung longer than it should have and then fell like a fruit that had deserved to be eaten. The second verse was the place they had reworked to make room for the life she could not bring to the stage literally; she placed the silence where the classroom lived and let the strings catch it as if it were a bird that had flown in accidentally and would not be manhandled. Halfway along it, someone shouted something inarticulate, the kind of shout that could unnerve you if you believed it had anything to do with you. She set her foot on the hinge and it held and nothing fell apart. The finish was less of a finish and more of a setting down, and the relief in the room felt like the sense of an old joke finally being shared with the right person.

The aftermath was the same and entirely different, because that is how repetition does its clever work. The panel said a thing they had meant or not meant and it mattered and it didn’t. The audience stood up or didn’t stand up as instructed by their own hearts or by the person at the end of the row with stronger feelings than sense. She came off and was grabbed for press and did not remember the words she said until someone sent them to her later with commentary. A woman she did not know held her by the shoulders and said “That was an answer to a question I hadn’t asked yet,” and then looked embarrassed and went away quickly before the moment could curdle. It was all human and ridiculous and beautiful and exhausting, and when the door to the corridor shut behind her she leaned on it and wanted very much to go to a place where the floor did not have tape on it telling her who to be.

She got that place on the train again, the ugly blessed carriage that took people back to kitchens they understood. The phone had messages in it like a river has fish, some you wanted to catch and some you hoped would find their own estuary. She scrolled and stopped and put it down and picked it up, because the muscle was new and twitchy. She saw one from a student who had left two years ago and was now, apparently, in the army, who wrote, “I thought it was daft when you made us write the letters to ourselves but I found mine in my drawer and it told me to keep going. Seeing you on the telly made me think I can do both the stupid job and the singing I do in my cupboard. Thank you. Don’t tell anyone I said thank you,” and she hid her face in her scarf for a second because it was her new favourite thing that she would tell no one about.

When the train tipped them into Dover, the air was colder in the useful way, as if the night had been saving a clean breath for her. She went home the long way again, because she was not ready for rooms. The harbour lights had their own idea of celebration, steady pulses instead of glitter. She could see, out beyond, the smudge of a ferry turning, its own small world of microwaves and children and truck drivers and a woman somewhere with a notebook making a list. The cat was there when she reached her street, of course it was, and this time it allowed itself to be picked up with the grace of a creature who understands PR.

Monday morning didn’t care how your Sunday had gone. School rolled over her like itself, and she was grateful. The fish were still alive; Gal made a small ceremony of being fed as if he intended to sign something official. Mr. Shaw had left another note, this time with detailed measurements and an apology to Marie Curie for earlier flippancy. The door banged and Year 9 arrived and they did their ritual of pretending they had nothing to say and then saying everything at once. Safia reported with authority that her uncle had cried “for no reason, which is to say a lot of reasons.” Noah said, very sternly, that he had noticed a comma missed in one of the captions and it had ruined the whole experience, and then he grinned in a way that said he had been proud enough to make himself dizzy.

At lunch, Mr. Barnes asked her to the hall and she went with obedient suspicion. The entire staff had organised an impromptu rehearsal of the wave generation, and somebody—of course Ms. Davis—had made a banner out of sugar paper and too much hope that read KEEP YOUR WEATHER, MISS FLINT, and she pretended not to cry and failed in a manageable way. In the afternoon, Mr. Sands brought her a photocopy of a song he had taken from some anthology three headteachers ago, and said without preamble, “If you go further, this might be for when you cannot imagine how to do it again. It doesn’t sound like you now. But it could.” He was a closed door that occasionally opened and put a cake on the mat.

There was, because the world requires balance, another message from the programme that had a perfunctory cheerfulness she had learned meant someone with a higher salary had had an idea. They wanted her to come to London Tuesday evening, not for singing but for sitting on a sofa and being gently interrogated by a presenter whose job it was to presume intimacy. “We think people want to learn more about you,” the producer said, steady and kind, and Hannah’s stomach did a thing she had not had time to schedule. She had the reflex to say no because of her children and her privacy and the fact that you cannot live on a sofa, but she also had a different reflex now that had been born the moment her song found its hinge on a stage with hot air and more opinions than lungs. She said yes and she wrote another set of cover notes and she was both glad and appalled that she had a system now for disappearing without cutting a child in half.

On the sofa, she found that the presenter was a person and not a machine and had a laugh that meandered on the way to its point, and that somebody had told him not to ask about her father, which meant something had been heard at some level. He did ask about the fish, and she told a national audience that her guppy had been poorly and that guppies could, in their way, be valiant, and the show cut to b-roll of a tank that was definitely not hers because her classroom did not have lighting like a spaceship. They gauzed Dover with a tenderness that made her forgive them, and when she spoke about teaching, they did not make that look like a fallback. If anybody read her words as a plea for sainthood, they did so without her permission.

Days spun. The second live show came nearer as if running downhill. She found that she had a new skill, which was recognising the exact moment when Ms. Davis had had too much of other people’s nonsense and diverting a child just before impact. She found that she could add salt to a tank without feeling like she was hexing the water. She found that she could ask for what she needed from the MD without fear that he would decide she was a diva and show her out. The song changed one more time in a way so small only they would notice, an extra breath at the front, and it made everything after it clearer. She thought of that change as an apology to the part of herself that had been told to be quiet for too long; she had given it a seat at the table first.

The morning of the second live, the sea went blue without being asked. She took her tea to the window and stood looking at the bit of town that had not moved since her childhood except where people had insisted on putting up new shades of paint and hope. The email pinged and she let it sit because she had learned that emails could wait for a second if you asked them to, and when she opened it, it was from a person who had nothing to do with television and everything to do with the other half of her life. It was from a woman who ran a little choir in a church hall that smelled of dust and biscuits; she wrote, “If you need a room to sing into with nobody in it and a piano that only sometimes pretends to be one, the key is still under the mat. I put new tea towels in. Your mum says she’ll tell you not to get ideas, by which she means please get ideas and then come home with them.”

In the corridor outside her classroom, a notice that hadn’t been there yesterday had been pinned up, and she paused. It was Ms. Davis’s handwriting again, tart and loopy. It said: “Resilience clinic. Free. Room 12. Bring your fear and a pencil.” Underneath someone had replied in a different hand: “Do you have pens.” Under that: “No.” Under that in another, smaller hand: “Can I bring a different fear than everyone else.” Someone had drawn a fish with a cape. Someone had underlined “free” twice as if to make the point. She stood there a second, the late morning sun finding a way down the rumpus of brick and glass, and let herself believe in the ordinary heroism of the people she worked with.

When she finally turned on the lamp of the tank and sprinkled the flakes, Gal came up from the plant like someone returning to work after having discovered they were not immortal. He took the food and didn’t posture, which in guppy terms was a mantra. He swam without drama. He left the mirror alone for a full two minutes. She watched him and the quiet he made felt like a promise you could write on your palm and not have it sweat off. She put her hand to the glass and he touched where she touched, drawn by whatever fish are drawn by, hunger or habit or heat.

“You and me,” she told him, because she had a ridiculous heart and it demanded ridiculous rituals. “We do it again. We make a small world make sense, and then we go out into the larger one and try not to let it unmake us.” He flared once, a tiny, dignified flare, as if to say he accepted the terms, and she laughed and turned to face a day that would require her to mark the difference between an adverb and an adjective in one hour and to stand between two forms of air in another. It would be, she thought, a day like any other, and it would be the day she had wanted since the silver thread had tugged her up in the dawn on Monday that felt like a decade ago. The kettle would shout. The gulls would hold their parliament. London would begin to warm its lights. She would take her banister in her hand when it was time to leave, and meet the stairs like a truth she could not unknow.Wednesday afternoon folded around her the way school days do when they know they are going to have to let you go early and are sulking about it. She spent the last lesson on grammar because grammar was ballast. They diagrammed sentences with the patience of archaeologists, and when Noah protested that nobody in the modern world needed to know what a subordinating conjunction was, she told him that knowing how things held together was never wasted, and he wrote a sentence that used three and then crossed two out because restraint is a muscle too. Safia read hers aloud like a person expecting the room to argue, and when it didn’t, she took the quiet as if it were a compliment. At the bell Hannah held them just long enough to say, “Be kind to each other while I’m gone. Don’t let anybody eat your lunch or your thunder. Do the homework. It will not kill you. If it does kill you, it will make an excellent piece of gothic writing.” They laughed and went, and she stood in their weather as it thinned.

In the corridor, a man with a camera who had absolutely been told he wasn’t to be here and had come anyway pretended to find the noticeboard fascinating. Mr. Barnes materialised like a moral and put his hand out for the man’s lanyard. “No children,” he said, not unkindly and not soft. “Not my walls. You want shots of inspirational footsteps, you film the staircase. You want inspirational people, you write to me and I tell you ‘no’ politely.” The man attempted charm and got back the expression that had retired three Ofsted inspectors in a row. He left, waving apologetically at the CPR dummy on the poster which, even moustached, looked unimpressed.

Hannah turned on the lamp in the tank for a last look and Gal obliged her by being ordinary. He lapped the filter, discovered it was the same filter as yesterday, and didn’t take offence. His tail was tattered still but less; like paper dried on a line after rain, it had remembered its own shape. She was surprised at how much energy it gave her, this small confirmation that mending could be noticed if you were patient enough to let your eyes settle. She spoke low to him because it helped her. “Spa, not disco,” she said. “Eat politely. Don’t make Mrs. Partridge from cleaning speak sharply to you because it will ruin your whole evening.”

She left cover work that even a stranger with a cold could deliver, labelled it like a military operation, and locked her cupboard against the part of herself that would, at nine p.m., mourn three red pens she hadn’t rescued. She went via the office to thank the receptionist for being the sort of person who kept the whole enterprise polite, and via the hall where Ms. Davis had written on the whiteboard for the resilience clinic a new line: You may bring biscuits. It will help nobody and change everything. Someone had drawn a lightning bolt that looked suspiciously like Mr. Shaw’s project from Year 8 electric circuits. She pictured him leaning on a desk with his porridge tie already on its second life of the day and felt the school in her bones as if it were weightlifting and she was unexpectedly good at it.

On the stairs, she did what she had promised herself she would always do if this kept happening. She paused with her hand around the banister and said out loud, because privacy is a relative concept in a building that contains a thousand hearts, “Thank you.” It was not to anything in particular and also to everything. She was a woman who had spent her twenties convinced gratitude was a posture and now had to be honest about the fact that it was a practice and better warmed you than not. Then she went; the day let her go; the wind outside had been saving up.

London received her with the air of a city that had already seen it all and might see it again if it felt like it. The building took her and the building took everyone, dog and drum boys and a man with a harmonica who had the ancient face of road and sleep. The runner with the clipboard who had adopted her as a project pointed her to a corner that would be hers for ten minutes and told her how we were running, and Hannah loved her in the way you love people who do not lie to you about time. The MD walked her through the small amendments they had set like stones, the breath before the first phrase, the decision not to let the strings show off, the agreement that silence would be part of the arrangement because you can arrange quiet if you’re brave enough. In the dressing room, the makeup woman had a steady hand and the professional malice for the cheap highlighter that had clearly broken three teenagers’ hearts this week; she swapped in a better kind with a calm “No sparkle at your age unless you’re a Christmas ornament,” and brushed Hannah’s eyebrows into submission, which made Safia’s voice run in her head, a warning and a grace.

When the stage manager came to collect the next set of trembling people, he looked at Hannah the way people do when they have decided they will behave like the inverse of a hurricane and the metaphor will hold if both of you hold it. “Same marks,” he said. “Different day. Don’t let the room tell you who you are. We can dim light; we cannot dim you. You do that or you don’t.” He was the priest of tape and doorways. She nodded and carried herself to the wings.

Out there, the room was full of air and noise and bright rules. The audience glittered like a night sea. She could not see faces and was grateful for it. The judges arranged themselves like small countries behind a border and she barely looked at them because her business was with the next breath and the next. The little red light came on in a place it had not been yesterday and it would have undone her once, the thought of so many eyes in so many rooms, but she had already spent a decade with thirty pairs of eyes on her every morning first thing, and those eyes were the unkindest and the kindest both, so she knew a thing about looking and stillness. The presenter said her name the way announcers say names when they don’t want to put their own weather in it, and she stepped forward and put her weather down like a rug.

The opening was clean because she asked it to be. The note sat where it had been told to sit, but like a living thing, not like a soldier. The strings found her without stepping on her heels. She looked nowhere and everywhere; she allowed herself, once, to look at a point where a person might be and was repaid by the oddest sense of being recognised by a stranger, which made your heart confused and your back straighten. Halfway through the second verse—the verse they’d carved to carry the classroom—someone in the balcony began to clap on a feeling, and others read the weather wrong and joined in because kindness is sometimes clumsy. She felt the rush of it come up toward her like a wind that hadn’t read the sign. She lifted her hand an inch and opened her fingers and did not look stern—she couldn’t; she could only look like a teacher asking for quiet with a smile—and the applause died as if she had put a coat over a parrot. She did not hurry to reward them for obeying. She put down the silence instead, and you could feel it, the room deciding to be held.

It trembled once; she held; the hinge held. She thought of the children when they breathed together and a noise that wanted to be mischief turned into listening because someone had made them want to be proud of themselves. She got to the place where the word ran up the hill and over, and she let it climb and did not overfeed it. The drum found her feet. At the end she did not put a flourish where none belonged. She let the music sit down and then she sat down with it, inside it, so that when the applause finally came, it came into a room that had not been startled but welcomed.

The panel said things. One of them said, “That’s control,” and meant it as a compliment and also like a warning, because people are suspicious of women who handle rooms. One of them made a joke about detentions for clapping and the camera found her laughing at herself, because self-ridicule is an easier public act than self-belief. One of them said something about a grandmother that the nation would relate to, and it washed over her harmlessly because she was busy feeling her pulse slow to a human animal’s. Above all, what she heard was the sound—a relief, a release, a decision—that comes from a crowd who have been given back to themselves. She took it in because it belonged to them and she was lucky enough to be present at the time of its happening.

Backstage, where light behaves differently, the MD shrugged one shoulder as if to say that was the tune, and the runner with the clipboard took a victory sip of water for her because she had been holding two clipboards and a radio and the fate of six latecomers. The dog did an interview and barked at the appropriate syllable. A man cried for fifteen seconds and then remembered that he did not do crying and instead absolutely had something in his eye. She went where she was told, said the things you say when someone with a bright microphone leans into your day and asks what it was like to be alive for two minutes; she did not know how to answer that without sounding facetious or enormous, and so she told a small truth that she knew would feed no wolves. She said, “They listened,” and the presenter said “We did,” and for once it felt true.

On the train back she had her face in a scarf again—not to hide, exactly, but to keep heat in—and the carriage did that thing of becoming briefly a village. Two older women watched her with proprietary fondness and showed each other photos of dogs not present. A boy moved seats because he had misjudged the smell of his crisps, and apologised, which looked a lot like grace. Across from her a teenager put a hand on his friend’s shoulder and said, in exactly the rhythm of the man she had seen days ago, “No melting,” and Hannah had to bite inside her cheek to keep from laughing and crying at the same time at the way even the tricks of breathing travel. Her phone was a beehive. She answered what she had the strength for, left the rest like nectar for later, and sent June a photo of the backstage curtain because it felt like the only true portrait of the night.

Dover made its case at midnight with a damp wind and an unambiguous horizon. She went the long way again because her nerves needed unpeopled distances and the comforting light of kebab shops. At the corner by the salon that turned hair into architecture, a car idled with music turned to thin. A seagull upended a bin with an air of civic purpose. The cat appeared at the bottom of her steps as if it had been contracted by a very quiet agency to greet and appraise. It suffered a kiss on the top of its head in order to collect rent. Inside, she laid the green dress over a chair like laundry because she refused to make a shrine of it. She took her makeup off with the dutifulness of someone taught by a mother who believed in clean faces and moisturiser as creed. In bed she fell asleep the way you fall into a swimming pool when you know it’s going to be cold and know you’ll be fine and do it anyway.

Morning made a liar of glamour. There was toothpaste to buy and register to cover and a note from the premises manager about the boiler that had tried to die again. The fish glowed in their own reasonable way and ate without theatre. Gal, now moving with a more modest flourish, acknowledged her with ignorance and need, which was always the agreement between them. In her inbox a message had arrived while she'd been in a green room, and for a second it looked like the sort of subject line you delete because you are not made of time. It said simply: Your father. She didn’t open it until break, when she had a biscuit in a napkin and the staffroom was in the quiet between two laughs.

The email was from Dorothy, of course. Dorothy did not write long and she did not write late unless it was worth it. Hannah read, felt the floor, kept reading. He had been in the shop, Dorothy wrote, because he had not been able to not, and June had been out back arranging old board games into piles by missing pieces and Dorothy had seen him first and made him tea without asking what he took because it was not that kind of day. He had said he had seen Hannah on the television and he had called her Hannah as if the word were unfamiliar and wanting to be practiced and Dorothy had said, After all this time, imagine, and he had winced as if hit and she had not apologised for the blow. He had left a card. He had said he would come back only if asked. Dorothy had suggested to him, in the tone she reserved for men and moths, that if he was waiting for women to ask, he would keep waiting for the rest of any decent life. He had not argued. The card was attached below, a scan that made his writing newly wretched, clumsy, older.

She stared at the looping letters like they were in code. He had not said much. He had said he was in Folkestone, which explained nothing. He had said he was glad to see she had used her lungs the way her mother had always wanted, which was an odd sentence to give a stranger to carry. He had said he was sorry without adjectives. He had written a number. He had not asked forgiveness as if he were entitled to it and he had not begged as if he were a child. He had done a very British thing and left a door ajar in case the weather changed.

She folded her biscuit in half and then into quarters because hands have to do something. It was notable that her heart did not start sprinting as if chased; it lifted into a light jog and then steadied. Mr. Barnes appeared with the slowness of friendship and Elaine from Geography, who knew every hill from here to Calais, slid a cup toward her. She did not say a thing about her father because there was no thing to say that had not already learned all the shapes of silence. She put the card under a book on subjunctives and let its corners flatten out.

The children were unbothered by the adult plotline they did not know about because their own stories were more urgent. A forgotten PE kit became an existential crisis for a boy who had never cried at anything school had thrown at him and now cried at cotton. A girl who had spent months refusing to write her name any way but suspended in the air wrote it on the line and blinked at her own practicality as if somebody had swapped her pen with a maturity. Safia brought in a news article about an opera singer whose throat had decided to go on strike and demanded in a way that made Hannah proud and nervous that the class talk about bodies and work and what you do when you want something and your body says no. They argued with respect and a few very excellent insults and wrote with care and then ruined their own carefulness with an extra adjective that some of them had the good grace to cross out.

Between the end of school and the next thing, she walked to June’s to pick up the card in its real cardboard. June sat with her foot up on the pouffe and her face arranged into a brave that was always only ever half real. They handled the card as if it was expensive and not from a pack you could buy for a pound in a petrol station. June didn’t tell Hannah what to do. She didn’t ask. She leaned her head against the chair and sang one line of a song without meaning to, a foolish old lullaby, and they both laughed because nerves will make you laugh at anything, especially tenderness. “He didn’t come in all at once,” June said finally. “He was a man who took a very long time to arrive everywhere, including himself. If you call him, call him as if he might get lost on the way and need to be fetched. And if you don’t call him, don’t call him. There’s no prize for either. I’m here afterwards either way.”

The show accordioned the week again, a strange concertina of normal and not. There was another rehearsal with the band, tighter, looser, sweeter. There was a fifteen-minute slot with a television person who seemed genuinely to believe that if the nation learned that Hannah liked cheddar more than brie, the nation might feel better about its own choices. There was a message from the man in Folkestone with the misspelled subject line that somehow made her forgive more than the content did—“Saw you again” with no punctuation, as if saying something without a capital would make it less dangerous. She replied with a sentence that did not close doors; she kept her weather. When she put her phone away after sending it, she put her hand flat on the desk of her classroom, on the gum that a hundred bored children had once stuck under there and been forgiven for, and felt the table forgive her back for whatever she was about to break or mend.

A parent did corner her one afternoon with the fierce politeness of someone who had spent too much of their life writing letters in blue ink. The woman had concerns about priorities. She had read—she didn’t like to say where—that fame could destabilise a person’s moral compass and the GCSE syllabus in one go. Hannah let the woman say it all because sometimes people have to hear themselves to know they are talking about their own fear. When she had finished, Hannah said, “Your daughter will get the same me she has always got. She will get the best me I can give. I will be here before the bell and after it. I will hold a space open for her and point at her commas. I will say no when she is unkind and yes when she risks being brave. And then I go to London and sing and it doesn’t take the chalk out of my hand. It just takes me for a bit and brings me back differently. If you like, you can not watch. If you like, you can come to parents’ evening and make me say all this again. I’ll say it as many times as you need.” The woman’s mouth went soft. She said, “All right,” as if she had expected to be argued with and someone had instead offered her a cup of tea. She sent a follow-up email with a single line: Thank you for doing both.

Some nights, when the house was very still and the cat had given up pretending it didn’t live there, she sang without sound. She shaped the words and let air do what sound would do without waking the neighbours or the griefs she had promised not to water after dark. She stood by the window and watched the ferry’s slow grace and felt the town at her back, a weight and a mercy. On one of those nights, when the day had been full of good small events and a single unignorable ache, her phone lit up with a message that said simply, Are you awake. She was, but she typed, I can be tomorrow, which was the kindest way of saying not yet. The reply did not come, which was a reply.

In the music room, Mr. Sands wrote a note on a scrap that then became important because he had written it. It said: The third song will need a different kind of quiet. Sit differently. He offered her nothing else, because he was not a man to apologise to a person for the mountains becoming steeper. She knew what he meant. The first quiet had been a held breath. The second had been a hand raised for hush. The third would be a silence you invited yourself into because you knew now it was a room and not an absence. She took the paper and put it in her pocket, and it warmed there until the next Wednesday, when she unfolded it and it made perfect sense, but only because she had had a Tuesday in between that contained three hours of detention, a child with a sore heart, and a gull so enormous it looked like a rumour.

The semi-final—that was the language other people used; she thought of it as another square of light—came nearer and brought with it a new kind of message from the programme. “We’re thinking,” the producer said carefully, “about a small… community element.” Hannah braced, because community in television is often code for tidy sentiment. “Not literal,” the woman went on, hearing her brace over the phone like a wire. “No children on a stage. We were humiliated by an ethics lecture from your headteacher and have come to respect the man. But a chalkboard. A desk. A light like late afternoon. If we do it right, it will look like where you live. You can say no. If you say no, we will do blue lights and pretend we thought of blue this morning.”

Hannah put the phone between her ear and shoulder and thought about the room and what it would think of being imitated. She pictured 9C as a ghost on a London soundstage and wanted not to cheapen it. She also wanted to honour the way a place shapes a voice. “Dust,” she heard herself say. “And a hum. You can fake the dust. The hum is harder. There’s a weather to the room. If you respect the weather, you can borrow it. If you don’t, you’ll break my heart and whatever’s left of your budget.” There was a delighted intake of air on the other end and the sound of a pen racing ahead of itself. “We can do hum,” the producer said. “We cannot believe we are having a conversation about hum. This is why these shows are ridiculous and magnificent.”

On the day itself—why pretend it was anything but a truer day dressed up—she arrived to find her life suggested in props. A chair that wasn’t her chair but understood chairness. A board cleaner that was too clean. A strip of light across a fake carpet that had the colour of the rectangle in her classroom when the sun was right, which made her forgive them their budget and their smoothing of rough edges. They had even made the air look worked-in, which was a level of artistry she had not expected. She ran her hands along the desk the way you pat a horse, half to calm it and half to calm yourself, and felt the slight give of set builders who had decided not to build the world out of lies. The MD lifted his chin at the light cue and she nodded because they were in agreement: weather first, notes second.

Her father sent a message that afternoon, a wiser one than the last. Can I come, it said, to the telly. Not there, she typed. Another time. Another place. Tea. It was generous and it wasn’t; it was a hand held out over the right body of water at least. He sent back, Tell me if sugar, and she had to sit down in the corridor because the sentence was plain and silly and contained more of him than any apology would have. She wrote, No sugar, because some truths you learn at six and keep. She did not tell June until after, because she was not unkind and because you cannot ask a mother to hold two kinds of nerves at once and still make a salad.

When she walked out, the dust and hum worked. The room was a suggestion of a room; the song did the rest. She placed the first word on the line where black marker met whiteboard and let the vowel find the corners. The arrangement sat under her like a piece of floor that had decided not to betray her today. They had added a single bell—light as the sound her fingernail made on the tank glass when she tapped good morning to Gal—and she had argued against it until she heard it and conceded that sometimes the cliché and the truth share a wardrobe. The audience quieted in phases. The judges did what judges do. The camera remembered to leave her eyes alone and look at her hands when she told it to with an angle of the wrist; she would not have known how to command that three weeks ago. Somewhere in the middle, in the place where Mr. Sands had promised a different quiet lived, she went there. She sat in the blank that wasn’t blank. She opened a door that hadn’t existed last month and found, behind it, not fear, but space.

After, you blink and find yourself in a room with fruit on a plate and people making noises like memory is hurting them. The runner with the clipboard looked like a person who had been asked to count rain, but she smiled and stuck a post-it to Hannah’s hand like a new sacrament. It had three names on it and a time and a note: Press friendly. Press-ish. Press no. She tried to follow the schedule and failed because life is the only thing that gets to be in charge. Someone from a newspaper with a reputation for cruelty asked her, with the elegance of a man trying to get blood out of a stone, whether there were any men in her life who might be proud tonight. She said, “Many,” and moved on before he could imagine he was one.

When it was over, over in the way that means there is always a next, she got the train back and turned off her phone for most of it and looked out of the dark into the dark and felt at home. At Dover, two boys tried to run on the platform and their mother snapped their names into obedience; then she put her hand on their heads gently because tenderness always apologises to discipline if it can. The cat was on the step with a new sense of itself; perhaps it had been complimented by a cameraman and would be unbearable for a week. She gave it dinner that would only encourage it. She took the note Mr. Sands had written and pinned it beside the fridge magnet that said BE NICE OR LEAVE and the electricity bill that made a case for revolution.

In the morning, the resilience clinic had acquired a queue and Ms. Davis was wearing a cape made of sarcasm and was dispensing pencils with the sternness of a pharmacist. “You don’t need an appointment,” she told a child who clearly wished she did. “You need a seat and a willingness to be improved. When I look at you, I see potential. When you look at me, you see me seeing your potential. Let us not waste each other’s time.” The child sat and took a breath and then another and then did their homework, which was a miracle in every direction and also, somehow, not unusual for a Tuesday.

Hannah took 9C through a poem that needed them, not because it was obvious but because it had hands the size of their hearts and they could feel themselves being held if they stopped showing off long enough. Noah found the word “ward” inside “toward” and made a joke bad enough to be an achievement. Safia asked if ambition ever calmed down and whether that meant you had to invent a new word once you got what you wanted because calling it ambition forever seemed unfair. They wrote with their heads tilted, the way people do when they are taking themselves seriously and don’t wish to be caught at it.

Midweek, Dorothy rang Hannah at school at exactly the wrong time and so it must have been important. “I have held him off three days,” she said, and Hannah parted her mouth to say “Who” and didn’t have to. “He is coming to the shop Thursday at ten,” Dorothy went on. “No grand entrances. I told him if he arrived like a trumpet I would send him to the Oxfam up the road. Bring your ordinary. Wear good shoes because I will make you stand if I need to tell him how much kneecaps cost.” Hannah agreed, and then put the phone in the drawer the way you put a fox in a shed; it was in there safely and you could hear it prowling anyway.

Thursday, she went. The morning had the thin beauty of biscuit tea. The shop smelled like old wool and soap and a little like last week’s fish from the market drifting in because it always did. June had her leg up and her lip bravado. Dorothy stood like a general. He came in as if the threshold were higher than it had ever been. He had the look of a man who had never not been tall and who had spent years attempting to shrink. The face was the one she remembered and not, grief and weather and the relief of having no-one to perform for writing their own lines. He took off his hat. He held it. He held himself like a person arriving late to the theatre and trying not to be seen. He saw her. She saw him. They did not do the television thing of making it a picture that someone would keep. They did the human thing of saying each other’s names as if they had to check they still worked in the mouth.

“Tea,” June said, with the iron-sweetness of people who have been kind for so long they use a different spice now. “Sugar?” He looked at Hannah and she shook her head and he shook his, and Dorothy made three mugs like an offering and put a plate between them that said, in capital letters, CAKE, as if anyone was unclear on what squares of sweetness could do. He said sorry like a man who had tried the word on in private until it fitted. She did not know what to do with it because apologies are not debts you can count. She said thank you because manners were scaffolding and she needed something to hold on to. He told her that he had a life up the road and it had not been a tidy one and he did not make excuses because excuses are a littering habit. He said he had watched her and felt complicated, and she said “Me too,” and they did a small, precise smile that only people unsure of the content of their own chests can do.

When she left the shop, Dorothy gave her a bag of picked-over paperbacks and said, “These are a prop in case anybody thinks you are a person who has never had to carry too much that didn’t belong to you,” and June kissed her palm and pressed it like a stamp. Outside, Dover had decided on bright. The sky treated their town like a thing worth making.

On Friday, Gal had regrown a rag-edge you could only see if you wanted to, and she wanted to. In class, they had a fire drill that did not feel like a drill to the Year 7 who had not yet learned that alarms are sometimes permission to chat and sometimes practice for not dying. She shepherded them into the cold and told a boy that he was not his panic, he was a person holding it, and he held it because she asked and because he could. Mr. Barnes wore his hi-vis vest like a coronation robe and counted with the bored omniscience of a man who had counted through wars. Ms. Davis confiscated chewing gum with a flourish. Mr. Shaw rescued a snail from a puddle with the care of a saint. The building let them back in because it held no grudge.

The programme wrote with more times, more rehearsals, more ideas you could say yes to without losing any of yourself you intended to keep. The MD handed her a new chart that looked like the same song had gone to a city and come back with a tattoo. Mr. Sands nodded at the hinge. The runner added a smiley face to her emails which meant she thought she and Hannah were friends now, and they were the sort of friends you become accidentally when you stand together in corridors holding other people’s hopes on clipboards.

On Saturday night, when the town pretended at being a different town and girls with jackets for shoulders walked too fast on thin heels, she went to the Mariner and sang without cameras, and Maggie gave her the look that meant no nonsense and also six chips on the house because Maggie believed in appropriate salt. A man in the corner always, always called for Wonderwall and another man always shouted him down and they both grinned because rituals keep us from believing time is random. Hannah sang a song she had not sung in years, one her mother had left in a drawer of the house they had lived in before this one, and it worked because the room had decided it would. She saw one of her Year 11s in the doorway and they froze and then remembered who they were supposed to be in public and acted accordingly. They sent her a message later that implied she had not seen them and also that they were extremely impressed.

Sunday came heavy and went light. She went to London with the feeling that the part of the story after this would be different if she made it so, and that she could not, after all, make the sea do anything but what it did. Backstage, someone had spilled glitter and someone else had looked at it like a crime scene. She walked out and found the shape and did the thing and heard the room happen. When the result came—because that is what these shows offer, an ending that isn’t—she felt the oddity she had not prepared for. She had been advanced; she had been chosen to go forward by the votes of a thousand living rooms and the calculation of two judges and a bit of luck, and she felt the relief and a nonsense grief for the people who would not go forward with her because you cannot carry everyone and that is unfair and exactly right.

She got home at dawn and let herself in and did the one thing that made sense. Before she put the kettle on, before she sent texts, before she allowed the day to stack its needs beside the sink, she fed the fish. They came like small suns. Gal arrived and performed a sensible arc. She tapped the glass and the sound was the same sound as ever, bell and nail, small and contained. “We won’t let it unmake us,” she told him, and he turned and vanished into his own water as if to say that he, at least, had figured that out. She made tea and stood at the window and watched Dover rehearse itself into the morning with the confidence of a town that has survived worse news and better and will again. She had songs to learn, she had books to mark, she had a father’s number in her phone and a mother’s voice in her ear and a fish with a fin like a flag not yet at full mast, and for once, she could stand in the middle of all of it and not feel like she needed permission. The gulls were up and ridiculous. The ferry sounded softly, a held note. She breathed and let the day happen the way weather happens—quietly and then all at once.Chapter 9

By the time Monday decided what to be, the town had already chosen its mood. Dover went with a blue that wanted to be taken seriously and a wind that kept trying the doorhandles. Hannah woke to the kettle’s old sermon and the cat on the windowsill doing its impression of a saint wronged. She made tea and fed the fish before she remembered to stand in front of the day and agree to it. Gal came up from the greenery in a measured way, not the swaggering charge of a week ago, and his tail had lost some of its raggedness, the edge silked back into itself like a torn shirt mended by a patient hand. He ate and did not perform, which in its own universe was a vow.

The email for the week had arrived in the night with times and rooms and the confident tone of a person writing down a tide table and believing it. Tuesday: press. Thursday: rehearsal. Sunday: show. The producer had written, lightly, Remember to breathe, and Hannah found herself annoyed and grateful because she possessed a professional stubbornness about being told to do the things she was already doing to stay alive. She put her hand on the banister as she left the flat, said thank you to nobody in particular like a person salting steps against ice, and went down into a morning that had put its collar on straight.

School was a machine too big to have feelings and yet somehow had them. The first bell made its own weather. A piece of paper on the staffroom table announced a bake sale in aid of something the geography department had started calling The Earth. Ms. Davis had expanded her Resilience Clinic hours and was already presiding at a table with a queue, dispensing stern permission slips for courage. Mr. Shaw had a new tie in a shade of porridge that suggested porridge had ambitions. Mr. Barnes moved down the corridor in his natural state, which was triumphant containment. In 9C, the fish engine hummed like a small vow and the board was clean. She wrote, under the date, A sentence is a kind of kindness if you let it be, and under that: Macbeth: the bits we missed because we were busy being brilliant.

They worked that first period with a steadiness that might have been boring if you had been untrained in the art of noticing. Noah introduced a clause that threatened to overwhelm the sentence and then cut it with a small show of grief and pride that only people who love commas can pull off. Safia sat differently, her chin up at an angle that suggested she was, for today, keeping several feelings in alphabetical order. A boy who had never understood that grammar was just a way to share a brain with someone else wrote four lines that were less like showing off and more like standing next to someone without startling them. The room warmed, not temperature so much as agreement.

At break a note came through the vaguely functioning internal post like a message in a bottle. Dorothy, said the front in her crabbed hand, and inside was the summary you would want from a person who made summaries out of chaos for a living. He will be in Thursday at ten, it said. He will be sorry at a level that may or may not be useful. You will be kind at a level that may or may not be wise. Bring biscuits. We will need ballast. Hannah folded the note and put it on top of the exercise books for 9C like a talisman. She lifted it, because you cannot ask talismans to carry actual work, and put it in her pocket.

She did the Tuesday publicity with a practiced wariness and a fledgling ease. A producer took them to the east pier for a shot that would never behave, gulls heckling like MPs and wind insisting on hair as theatre. The camerawoman with the nose ring, who had now become Hannah’s favourite because she did her job without needing to be seen doing it, filmed Hannah walking along the railings as if the railings had written to request it. They filmed the tank again with extreme tenderness, and the sound man spoke reverently into his furry microphone as if it were a small animal that would be offended by lies. They placed a light in her classroom that made the dust look like a choice. She let them, because sometimes you can tell when somebody is borrowing the truth and not stealing it.

In the corridor afterward, a man with a lanyard asked for a comment about her journey and Ms. Davis walked past and said briskly, “It’s a noun that has been tortured,” and everyone laughed the slightly wicked laugh of people who needed to move the world forward a fraction and knew the only available lever was humour. The local paper sent a boy so new he had elbows for personality and he asked Hannah if she had any regrets. “Loads,” she said, because it was the only honest answer and because she liked to leave a young journalist with a clean sentence even if it made no headline.

The producer rang the next day to talk about the final song in a tone that pretended it wasn’t called a final. “We’re hearing it with a swell,” she said, clicking a pen like a metronome. “Not a syrupy one. Something that says ferry, not wedding. The MD is thinking low brass, a suggestion of horn, the sound that holds the bottom of a room up when a voice gets brave.”

“Not a trumpet,” Hannah said, thinking of men on small stages doing too much with their cheeks. “Something that remembers being useful in fog.”

“Exactly,” the woman said, relieved as if somebody had named the weather. “And as for the set—”

“No children,” Hannah said, because she would not let her classroom be converted into a moral she didn’t control. “But a board. A line of light. Something chalky that isn’t literal chalk. And if you can make the hum, you can have it. If you can’t, we go simple and let the sound do the work.”

“The hum,” the woman repeated, half laughing, half determined. “God help us, we’re staging hum. I’ll have props and lighting cry into their lattes and then make me proud.”

On Thursday, she put on a coat that made her look like the sort of person who returned phone calls on time and went to the charity shop at ten. It felt too early for reconciliation and exactly right for tea. June had reorganised the shelves with her own logic, biographies next to whisk recipes and a stack of crime novels smiling at a broken clock. Dorothy stood behind the till like a bouncer at a church fete. He came in as if the bell didn’t want to ring for him. He had a hat because men like him think hats make them better behaved. He took it off and held it, which was almost a prayer. He had her mouth and somebody else’s sorrow. He said her name like a listener testing a speaker. She said his like she was making a list and stumbled over nothing and considered it a victory that her voice didn’t wobble around the edge of old.

They sat on the chairs that had belonged to a wedding and a church and now to the general public. Dorothy brought tea with the moral heft of a union leader and put the plate of cake between them as if marking on a map where conversations can pivot. He said sorry with less drama than television would want and more care than she had given him credit for. He mentioned a town up the road, a job in a place that smelled of oil and time, the years he had spent talking himself out of movies in which he knocked on doors and was considerate at last. He did not ask for forgiveness as if it were a prescription. He put a card on the table as if he might be asked for proof of existence. He laughed once at himself and did not linger in the laugh as men sometimes do when they are pleased with their own charm. He looked at June the way a man looks at a mountain he did not climb because the weather he had brought was wrong.

June was magnificent and ordinary, which is to say she did not make of the moment a statue. She poured tea and enquired after weather and handed him the biscuit with the most jam like a queen and would not have him say more than the room could hold without cracking. “We like you alive,” she said, when he said he did not deserve it, and that seemed to satisfy her terms. He asked if he could hear Hannah sing in a room that was not on the television and Hannah said yes in the restrained, risky way of someone who had decided to be specific. “The Mariner,” she said. “Saturday. Maggie has rules. And chips. Chips most of all.”

When she left them, the sky over the High Street had gone fat with possibility. She carried an empty shopping bag so she would look like a person on an errand and not like a person who had changed the way she carried her own past. She went back to school through the narrow bit where the wall leaned in and down the stairs, touching the banister twice on the same journey for luck or because she couldn’t help it.

In 9C, Noah was trying to build a sentence that could carry a thought without collapsing and was making the face of a person who insists on carrying the wardrobe alone. “Two verbs,” she told him, gentle with the truth and stingy with unnecessary mercy. “One of them can carry. One must sit down.” He snorted and made the cut and then pretended the relief belonged to nobody. Safia rolled her eyes at a line in Macbeth and then read it out like she had written it and wanted feedback, which is as much as you can ask of anyone. At the end of the period, a girl who never spoke first walked up and said, “Miss, when you’re on the telly and they clap at the wrong time, it annoys me. Not because it’s wrong, just because it’s wrong. Anyway.” She left, and Hannah stood a moment longer to feel the gift of that wrong-shaped confidence being handed over with a shrug.

The set rehearsal on Thursday was a lesson in faith placed in people who have a religion called Lighting. The props team had made dust without making it sentimental. The sound tech had found a hum in a box and then tuned it so it felt like a building breathing. The MD stood with his low brass and his string section and in the half-light the instruments made shadows that looked like old ships. They tried the first verse in a key that made her voice brace and then undo, and she said, quietly because you do not shout at people trying to help you, “One lower,” and he nodded because this was the work and not a favour. The bell they had argued about came once like a coin under water and because it was not forced it didn’t make her hate it. She stepped into the hinge and this time handled it without stepping on its foot. The second quiet—that was last week’s trick. The third was a room you had to find without eyes. She felt it open somewhere between her chest and the part of the stage she might have claimed if she were a different woman. She sat down in it and did not apologise.

Friday, the tank decided to have an opinion. She came in from a lunch duty that had involved persuading a group of Year 8 boys that arguing about crisps loudly does not make them philosophers, and heard a sound that did not belong. The filter was working too hard or not hard enough; she couldn’t tell with machines that lived under water. Gal hung in the corner with the program of a man who wanted to be left alone to make his own foolish mistakes. She turned off the lamp, turned it on again, watched the bubbles. Mr. Shaw arrived like luck and leaned down so hard his tie dipped and came up printed with flecks like confetti. “We’ll syphon,” he said, the way you say “We’ll march” if you have a different kind of job. He produced a tube from a cupboard that shouldn’t have contained it and a bucket that had once held custard and the air in the room changed from panic to a plan.

Safia and Noah were deputised as junior aquarists and took the roles with the gravity of an emergency. “Spa, not disco,” Hannah reminded them, and they worked as if the phrase had been part of a sacred text. Water slid obediently into the bucket and the bucket into the sink and the sink tried to be helpful. Gal, to his credit, did not take the opportunity to make himself into a Greek tragedy; he held his water and his temper. When they had refilled and salted and turned the lamp down to mood rather than theatre, the tank settled into its hum like a person into a chair. “We can’t fix everything,” Mr. Shaw said, not looking at her, because kindness does not make eye contact while it’s being the truth. “But we can keep the water decent.”

The Mariner on Saturday smelled like a decision. Maggie pretended to be cross about the televisions and was actually pleased, and she announced to the bar that “the rules still apply” as if she were guarding over a moral code and a jukebox. Hannah wore ordinary clothes that looked deceptive in their effort, and when she sang the first song the room behaved itself like a Wednesday church that had understood the sermon. In the second, she saw the door open and a hat appear and the man under it fail to come in and she sang anyway because she had not changed the rule that you do not chase people into rooms they have not chosen. Dorothy, who had honed the art of seeing without intruding, ghosted into the doorway at the same moment and performed a glance that asked a question and got the answer it had expected; she nodded, went back to June, and left the door ajar. Hannah closed her eyes long enough to feel the ache and not long enough to make a theatre of it. She opened them and the room gave her back to herself with the usual gifts, the chips and the laughter and the man who always wanted Wonderwall and the man who always forbade it and their little play inside her bigger one, which was all any of them could reasonably carry.

The Sunday of the final refused to behave like a special day. It was the same kettle and the same thin light through her kitchen blind and the same cat with the opinion of a baronet. June sent a text that was an emoji of a potato because she had discovered them in her phone and would not be dissuaded. Ms. Davis sent a picture of a pencil like a baton. Mr. Barnes sent a photograph of a tie that looked illegal. Mr. Sands sent no picture, only words: Sit differently. The MD sent a link to a clip of a cello being tuned in a church and a sentence that said, oddly, this is the hum. Dorothy sent, briskly, Weather fine at ten today. Your father not dead. Your mother very alive. Don’t trip.

Backstage had learned her shape by now and did not jostle. The runner with the clipboard had spent her week on other people’s accounts of fear and had not lost her manners; she handed Hannah a microphone like a chalice and said, “We’ve lit the hum,” and did not laugh at herself. The brass did their private rituals, oil and breath and grimaces. The strings were warm. The bell waited to be rung and did not mind whether it was in a song or a desk somewhere. The stage manager checked the tape marks on the floor as if they were a low code for a landing. The light guy had found a way to make the dust glint once and then forget itself, which was the line between sentimentality and art and he had managed to step on the right side of it. Hannah stood in the wings and thought of all her banisters and in doing so made a rope with them and found she could hold it. She thought of the tank, which now made peace reliably enough to be taken for granted, and of Gal, who had chosen, in recent days, the path of ordinary life as a means of carrying on. She thought of her father’s hat in a doorway and of her mother’s peas and of a house where a cupboard was closed and wouldn’t cry until later.

They called her name without ceremony because the ceremony is the bit that costs and her portion had already been spent on light. She stepped out and placed her feet where the tape said the world would hold them. The audience went to the place they had learned to go when a song began to make a room without their help. She put the first word on the board inside her head and watched it write itself in a hand she recognised. The brass under her didn’t elbow; they shouldered. The strings laid a tablecloth and stood back. She breathed for the length of a ferry’s horn and began.

She let the second verse pick up the day and put it down without breaking the handle. The third quiet came like a corridor you had to go down alone and she went down it and found at the end a window she could open with one hand. She felt the bell arrive the way you feel a guest you were dreading surprise you by wiping their feet. The room did the right sound. The judges did their jobs. She did not look at them. She looked up where the dust lived and told the dust something without words about second chances and small engines and ferries that come when they say they will, and then she lifted the last words off the table as if they were a good plate and you were closing the kitchen for the night.

There were the noises. There always are. Approval. The particular applause that is relief pretending to be celebration. The voice of a man who gets paid to turn his feelings into an instruction telling people to vote. The red light where the camera lived like an obedient star. She said the appropriate sentences to a presenter whose kindness was real enough to be useful. The panel said sentences that would make sense in other kitchens later. She left by the door you leave when you’re needed somewhere else. In a corridor, the runner put her hand on Hannah’s arm for a thickness of a second and said, “Good,” and nobody argued with her, which, in television, is almost a miracle.

On the train home, she turned her phone over and back on the little table as if it were a coin deciding what to be. Messages piled on each other like puppies; she sorted them with the practiced absence of a teacher marking thirty books in an hour, lightly, while saving the heavy attention for what plainly needed it. June sent a photograph of Dorothy asleep on the charity shop sofa in a position that suggested she had won a fight with gravity. Mr. Barnes had recorded his television saying “Miss Flint” out loud and sent her the clip with the caption: I have trained the machine. Ms. Davis had written, Resilience clinic fully booked. Will now be franchising. Mr. Sands had written only, Nice chair, by which he meant: you sat differently and it worked. Her father had written, Only cried once, and she put her head in her scarf for a moment because she had not thought to measure herself against that unit.

Dover was cold and clean and unfazed when she arrived back in it, which helped. The cat considered the question of appearing surprised and decided it was beneath her. The dress for once did not get the chair; it went straight to a hanger like a person with a mortgage. She put the kettle on and stood at the window, the old indulgence of watching a town practice being itself before she rejoined it. She slept without needing to talk herself into it, coin-drop, cool.

Monday decided it wanted to be mostly Year 9. They arrived with news written on their foreheads and a craving for ordinary like you crave salt. Safia had perfected an eyebrow that said you had done well without endorsing anything that might embarrass her; she did it twice, which amounted to parental approval. Noah had written a letter to his future self that contained a joke so dreadful it made its own weather and an instruction to remember how to breathe on trains; he pretended he had written it for homework and not because of feeling. A boy whose talent was to laugh loudly at the wrong time managed to sit through the hinge of a poem without exploding and then went out into the corridor and ran a lap to disperse the pressure. In the tank, Gal did a tour like a general reassuring his troops that, sorry, the hum will continue. There was a lurch at lunchtime because someone had written something about her online that stung for six minutes and seventy-two hours at once, and Ms. Davis confiscated her phone the way she confiscated gum and handed it back with the authority of a pharmacist. “One an hour,” she said. “Or you will rot your teeth.”

There were practicalities because real life is always practicalities no matter how the lights behave elsewhere. She did an inventory of glue sticks and found it wanting. She set detention for three people who had done nothing wrong except perform their despair at the wrong time and she sat with them while they did their homework as if they had meant to. She filled in a spreadsheet that pretended to track meaning. She called a parent and said, carefully, that their child was nearly a poem. She met with the head and the woman with concerns and left with less bureaucracy and more cake than she had thought possible.

The message from the programme that night had a different colour to it; victory and its obligations threaded through the lines. Schedules with earlier mornings, rehearsals that would demand her other hands. There would be a filmed piece in Dover, with the permission of those willing, about where she sang when nobody listened and she put a stop sign on the charity shop by writing a single sentence: My mother does not belong to you. The producer, to her credit, wrote back, Absolutely, and added three hearts and the phrase, Against form, which made Hannah like her more.

In the quiet square of late, when the cat had admitted defeat and slept unguarded and the radiators sighed like an old ship docking, she took out the card from her father and held it under the lamp. He had a number and the barest bones of a signature and a blot where the pen had refused and he had forced it. She dialled because she did not like to teach children courage and not model it at least in small, survivable amounts. It rang. He answered with the startled sound of someone not used to receiving anything he wanted. They arranged tea without saying the word sorry again, which felt sane. “The pier café,” he said, grateful to have a noun to hide behind, and she said “Yes,” and then they hung up before politeness could get in the way.

He was there on Wednesday with his hat and everything he had not known how to offer. The pier café remembered him without permission because buildings keep secrets and refuse to divulge unless asked kindly. They chose a table by the window where the light forgave them both. He told her a story about a ferry he had nearly missed in 1993 and the woman he had admired on it for three hours and the fact that when the ferry docked he had not followed her because the idea of her had become something else and his courage had been spent on making the story instead. He told her a smaller story about a budgie he had kept for a winter when Hanna was little and then given away because its happiness had become a mirror. He didn’t explain the metaphor because the café would not have survived it. He asked her, halting, for a selection of nothing that added up to permission. She gave him some. He did not press her for more. He looked at her mouth when she spoke as if to reassure himself that it still worked like his did. He paid and pretended not to. They left together and gave the gulls a thing to comment on and parted before the point where they might have tried to fix more than a morning could hold.

It was a good day to teach Macbeth. The class took delight in the witchy bits in a way that would have concerned the medieval but was perfectly healthy in a building with three fire extinguishers per floor. “Vaulting ambition, which o’erleaps itself and falls on the other,” Hannah wrote, and Safia muttered under her breath that sometimes ambition just tripped on a step and made a noise and kept going, which felt like a modern footnote. Noah asked whether Macbeth would have been happier as a teacher and then answered himself with a brisk “No,” which made the room exhale. They drew lines on the board not because they were making graphs but because sometimes you need to make a visible path between a feeling and a word.

On Thursday, the programme came with a small swarm to film conversations they would later call “packages,” and 9C pretended to be uninterested while clearly measuring how this would accumulate into story. Mr. Barnes held the line like a man on a towpath and the crew were good and careful and took off their hats again. The boy with the loud laugh pressed his lips tight until the camera went past and then was released and laughed the laugh of a person who had survived being quiet in public. They filmed the outside of the school and the inside of the sea and something in between, and even Ms. Davis admitted in the staffroom afterward that the nose-ringed camerawoman had an eye for hum and left the biscuit plate suspiciously emptier than before, which was as close as she got to a compliment.

The final rehearsal in London was less about notes now and more about spine. The MD did not stop the band between phrases to fix; he adjusted air. “From the breath,” he kept saying, not because he was in love with a metaphor but because he had made a habit of being right. The stage manager marked the places where panic tends to pool, the corners and the middle and the bit where your shoe snags on tape that was not there yesterday. The runner now knew her tea order and the fact that before walking out Hannah liked the feel of a pencil in her pocket even though there was nothing to write on out there; she put one there without comment and ticked a box you will not find on any form.

Saturday night, Dover did its best impression of a different town again and put pinks in the sky it couldn’t afford. The Mariner was full of a kind of pride that did not require anybody to lower their eyes. Maggie gave Hannah a look that said no nonsense and everything and handed her a piece of bread that felt medicinal. A man in a corner wiped his eyes and nobody saw him do it. A girl from Year 11 thought she was invisible until Hannah waved at her and then remembered she was supposed to be someone else in public and posed, badly, for a selfie she would later pretend had been ironic. Hannah sang a song that had more air than sound in it, because the room would let her, and a woman from Wales who was nobody’s aunt gave her a hug afterward that smelled of lamb fat and laundry and left her steadier than she had any right to be.

Sunday morning she put her coat on and did the thing she had done enough times now that the place between nerves and ritual had become habitable. Tea. Fish. Hand on banister. The hum. She went to London and the city pretended it had been waiting. In the wings she put her hand flat on the wall and thanked it, because she had become a person who thanked bricks. The MD looked at her and did not say good luck, because men like him do not believe luck should take the credit. He lifted his hand and she nodded and they both had the unglamorous look of people who are about to do exactly what they said they would do.

Out there, the hum had been installed. The board shone because someone had wiped it down with a ferocity usually reserved for sins. The light lay on the fake carpet like a real one waits for the day’s first foot. She stepped into her mark and spoke the first line into a room that had agreed, for a handful of minutes, to be a classroom without walls, and the sound went up and came down and didn’t break, and the show did what shows have done for a hundred years in halls with dusty curtains and cavernous ceilings and had the decency to get out of the way.

Later, on the train that was rapidly becoming a second living room, her phone would buzz with a message from a stranger that said, in the rough grammar of someone who valued urgency over correctness, “You made me think. And I’m not a thinker. Don’t tell my husband.” June would send a photo of a potato that had been carved into a heart because someone had come into the charity shop that afternoon with nothing to do and too many knives, and Dorothy would caption it, Art, and add, in a second message, He doesn’t wear the hat indoors, marriage saved. Mr. Barnes would send a video of his tie hanging over the end of his banister like a flag at half mast and a line: We will require cake. Ms. Davis would send nothing but leave a pencil on Hannah’s desk the next morning, point sharpened, eraser unused, and the resilience clinic would have a sign-up sheet with three pages of names, none of whom were in need of anything a biscuit could not at least begin to address. Mr. Shaw would tie a new tie in the morning because porridge, left unsupervised, is a destiny.

Before all that, though, there was the night and the step and the hush and the hinge and the bell and the line where breath became note and note became a room and the room became, for once, a place where she could put down everything she was carrying and not be asked for a receipt. The ferries would still move; the gulls would still scream like a committee; the fish would still discover the same filter and not be disappointed. She would still go back and mark the subordinate clause and explain to a child that sometimes the moral of a story is that you are tired and you should go to sleep. She would still answer the phone to her father and say, Yes, tea, the pier café, two sugars for nobody. She would still make a note and put it on her kitchen table that nobody would see: Feed fish. Breathe. Okay. She would still laugh at herself for needing instructions and then follow them like a person who had finally decided to be kind.

It was when she was standing in her kitchen later, the dress hung up like evidence, the cat deciding whether to purr or litigate, that the email arrived with the sort of subject line that knows it is important and has not yet learned humility. Congratulations, it said, and gave a time and a date and a list of obligations that would reshape her next month like weather. The finals would not be a single night but a campaign.
