He answered with the startled sound of someone not used to receiving anything he wanted. They arranged tea without saying the word sorry again, which felt sane. “The pier café,” he said, grateful to have a noun to hide behind, and she said “Yes,” and then they hung up before politeness could get in the way.

He was there on Wednesday with his hat and everything he had not known how to offer. The pier café remembered him without permission because buildings keep secrets and refuse to divulge unless asked kindly. They chose a table by the window where the light forgave them both. He told her a story about a ferry he had nearly missed in 1993 and the woman he had admired on it for three hours and the fact that when the ferry docked he had not followed her because the idea of her had become something else and his courage had been spent on making the story instead. He told her a smaller story about a budgie he had kept for a winter when Hanna was little and then given away because its happiness had become a mirror. He didn’t explain the metaphor because the café would not have survived it. He asked her, halting, for a selection of nothing that added up to permission. She gave him some. He did not press her for more. He looked at her mouth when she spoke as if to reassure himself that it still worked like his did. He paid and pretended not to. They left together and gave the gulls a thing to comment on and parted before the point where they might have tried to fix more than a morning could hold.

It was a good day to teach Macbeth. The class took delight in the witchy bits in a way that would have concerned the medieval but was perfectly healthy in a building with three fire extinguishers per floor. “Vaulting ambition, which o’erleaps itself and falls on the other,” Hannah wrote, and Safia muttered under her breath that sometimes ambition just tripped on a step and made a noise and kept going, which felt like a modern footnote. Noah asked whether Macbeth would have been happier as a teacher and then answered himself with a brisk “No,” which made the room exhale. They drew lines on the board not because they were making graphs but because sometimes you need to make a visible path between a feeling and a word.

On Thursday, the programme came with a small swarm to film conversations they would later call “packages,” and 9C pretended to be uninterested while clearly measuring how this would accumulate into story. Mr. Barnes held the line like a man on a towpath and the crew were good and careful and took off their hats again. The boy with the loud laugh pressed his lips tight until the camera went past and then was released and laughed the laugh of a person who had survived being quiet in public. They filmed the outside of the school and the inside of the sea and something in between, and even Ms. Davis admitted in the staffroom afterward that the nose-ringed camerawoman had an eye for hum and left the biscuit plate suspiciously emptier than before, which was as close as she got to a compliment.

The final rehearsal in London was less about notes now and more about spine. The MD did not stop the band between phrases to fix; he adjusted air. “From the breath,” he kept saying, not because he was in love with a metaphor but because he had made a habit of being right. The stage manager marked the places where panic tends to pool, the corners and the middle and the bit where your shoe snags on tape that was not there yesterday. The runner now knew her tea order and the fact that before walking out Hannah liked the feel of a pencil in her pocket even though there was nothing to write on out there; she put one there without comment and ticked a box you will not find on any form.

Saturday night, Dover did its best impression of a different town again and put pinks in the sky it couldn’t afford. The Mariner was full of a kind of pride that did not require anybody to lower their eyes. Maggie gave Hannah a look that said no nonsense and everything and handed her a piece of bread that felt medicinal. A man in a corner wiped his eyes and nobody saw him do it. A girl from Year 11 thought she was invisible until Hannah waved at her and then remembered she was supposed to be someone else in public and posed, badly, for a selfie she would later pretend had been ironic. Hannah sang a song that had more air than sound in it, because the room would let her, and a woman from Wales who was nobody’s aunt gave her a hug afterward that smelled of lamb fat and laundry and left her steadier than she had any right to be.

Sunday morning she put her coat on and did the thing she had done enough times now that the place between nerves and ritual had become habitable. Tea. Fish. Hand on banister. The hum. She went to London and the city pretended it had been waiting. In the wings she put her hand flat on the wall and thanked it, because she had become a person who thanked bricks. The MD looked at her and did not say good luck, because men like him do not believe luck should take the credit. He lifted his hand and she nodded and they both had the unglamorous look of people who are about to do exactly what they said they would do.

Out there, the hum had been installed. The board shone because someone had wiped it down with a ferocity usually reserved for sins. The light lay on the fake carpet like a real one waits for the day’s first foot. She stepped into her mark and spoke the first line into a room that had agreed, for a handful of minutes, to be a classroom without walls, and the sound went up and came down and didn’t break, and the show did what shows have done for a hundred years in halls with dusty curtains and cavernous ceilings and had the decency to get out of the way.

Later, on the train that was rapidly becoming a second living room, her phone would buzz with a message from a stranger that said, in the rough grammar of someone who valued urgency over correctness, “You made me think. And I’m not a thinker. Don’t tell my husband.” June would send a photo of a potato that had been carved into a heart because someone had come into the charity shop that afternoon with nothing to do and too many knives, and Dorothy would caption it, Art, and add, in a second message, He doesn’t wear the hat indoors, marriage saved. Mr. Barnes would send a video of his tie hanging over the end of his banister like a flag at half mast and a line: We will require cake. Ms. Davis would send nothing but leave a pencil on Hannah’s desk the next morning, point sharpened, eraser unused, and the resilience clinic would have a sign-up sheet with three pages of names, none of whom were in need of anything a biscuit could not at least begin to address. Mr. Shaw would tie a new tie in the morning because porridge, left unsupervised, is a destiny.

Before all that, though, there was the night and the step and the hush and the hinge and the bell and the line where breath became note and note became a room and the room became, for once, a place where she could put down everything she was carrying and not be asked for a receipt. The ferries would still move; the gulls would still scream like a committee; the fish would still discover the same filter and not be disappointed. She would still go back and mark the subordinate clause and explain to a child that sometimes the moral of a story is that you are tired and you should go to sleep. She would still answer the phone to her father and say, Yes, tea, the pier café, two sugars for nobody. She would still make a note and put it on her kitchen table that nobody would see: Feed fish. Breathe. Okay. She would still laugh at herself for needing instructions and then follow them like a person who had finally decided to be kind.

It was when she was standing in her kitchen later, the dress hung up like evidence, the cat deciding whether to purr or litigate, that the email arrived with the sort of subject line that knows it is important and has not yet learned humility. Congratulations, it said, and gave a time and a date and a list of obligations that would reshape her next month like weather. The finals would not be a single night but a campaign. She had become a person whose life would, temporarily, be written as a schedule and she was not frightened in the way she had expected to be. She took it in and turned off the light and went to the window and looked at Dover being exactly Dover. The ferry sounded an old note. In the tank, the engine hummed like a promise made by someone ordinary and kept. She put her hand to the glass and Gal came, not because love works like that but because hunger and light do, and she laughed at the analogy and forgave herself the cheapness and went to bed.

The next days did that trick time does when it knows you’re watching: they went both slow and very fast. In school, they diagrammed sentences because sentences are the bones of courage, and when Noah tried to add a fourth clause as if making an argument louder made it right, she raised an eyebrow he had learned to respect and he sighed and cut it and beamed without admitting it. Safia wrote an essay that ended with a question and then a statement and then crossed out the question, a victory of discipline over drama that could have been taught but had in the end been decided. A boy who was not a reader came in carrying a paperback as if it were a mug that might spill, and when she asked him why he had it he said, as if confessing to a crime, “It had a dragon,” and she nodded because all decent roads begin with dragons. The resilience clinic introduced a sign that read: You are allowed to bring a friend. You are not allowed to bring a flame thrower. The graph of improvement grew like vines around the windows of Room 12. Ms. Davis adjusted a cape none of them could see and took attendance as if it were a sacrament.

In Dover, the charity shop saw a run on dresses for weddings that had not yet been proposed. June presided like a benevolent weather front, and the shop briefly became a station where half of town came to admit small hopes and be assigned a price sticker appropriate to their budget. Dorothy wrote a sign that said: Advice is free. Sarcasm is extra. Remarkably few people paid, perhaps because Dorothy, when asked, refused to accept anything but cake.

London asked for more of her than it had before and she said yes without bleeding in public. The MD added a thread of harmony that made the bell look over its shoulder. The low brass did a rehearsal with the door open and a man from a different show put his head in, frowned, and then nodded and walked on as if checking the weather for a trip he had not yet booked. The runner with the clipboard had officially run out of battery and yet somehow kept going, her hair now permanently part of the communications system. A wardrobe woman with the bite of a good sister insisted on different shoes because you cannot stand in that place wearing hope alone; your feet will have opinions.

On a Thursday that started with rain and the taste of metal and ended with a rainbow that refused to be twee because it had to exist somewhere, her father sent a photograph of a mug with a tea stain on a saucer and the edge of a newspaper and a line: Three things I brought with me to the coast: a book I pretended to read, a regret I’ve stopped polishing, and a thermos. I wouldn’t mind if I had to share the thermos one day. She sent back a picture of a pencil and a kettle and a fish, and he replied with a series of question marks that made her smile in spite of her caution. June, uninvited to that exchange, texted an entirely unnecessary warning about men and the way they mistake showing up for penance and then undercut herself with, Bring potatoes Sunday. Dorothy, not given to subtlety, wrote: You’re allowed to send him for milk and not say thank you.

When the call sheet for the final-final came through, it had that alarming link of columns and obligations that had once made her think of air traffic control and now made her think of school timetables; confusing until lived, then automatic. They wanted an interview where she talked about what singing had saved her from. She wrote back and said in as many words that the interesting thing was that teaching had saved her, too, and where would they like to put that, and the producer sent a reply composed entirely of exclamation marks and the word Yes, repeated until it bored even itself and became moving. They wanted a shot of her in the empty classroom after the last bell, and she told them to take off their hats, and they did, and the room agreed to be a television for twenty minutes and then returned to itself as if television were a weather that passed.

The cat, because it was not owned by anyone’s narrative, developed a cough that lasted briefly and with a drama that threatened to destabilise the entire week and then disappeared as if purchased, used, and returned. The neighbour upstairs continued to do soundproofing to an unknown end result. The banister continued to offer itself and she continued to take it. The fish hummed. The engine hummed. The town hummed. The song in her chest hummed. She went to London and said yes to a microphone and no to a director who wanted her to turn and look at the camera on the word love, politely, because that was a stage direction her body would not obey without lying. She opted for speaking the word as if it were an object you set down carefully, and he threw his hands up and said, “Fine, fine, art,” and then turned to terrorise somebody who had wanted to be terrified.

On the night itself—the last one they would count and then insist meant the most—she stood in the wing and thought of the cards she had been dealt and the ones she had refused and the ones she had not even seen on the table. She felt the hinge under her feet as a promise and not a trap. She lifted her head because Mr. Sands would have said so and she had learned that listening to him made a life easier in ways that were not always musical. She went out into the light and said the first line in the voice of a person who knew that endings are sluttish things and will go where they want, and she did not begrudge them. She asked the room for a quiet that was not silence but a kind of attention, and the room, small miracle of strangers, gave it. She stepped through and did not fall.

Whatever was going to happen that night happened the way wind happens—according to rules and without them. Someone would win and she might not and it would be both important and not. She would go back to school and tell Noah to be kind to his adverbs and tell Safia that she could hold the middle of an argument without declaring war. She would go to the pier café and drink tea with a man who had been late his whole life and had brought a thermos as proof of intention. She would stand in a charity shop and be assigned a price that would make someone believe in their own reflection for an hour. She would watch a fish regrow himself into something like grace. She would put her hand on the banister and feel it cool under her palm and think, every time, of all the ways you can go down without falling.

And when, very late and then too early, she woke up into the sad sweetness of after, she would feed the fish before she made tea because that was the order that made sense to her, and Gal would present himself like a small sun and take what she gave and swim on like an agreement made between two creatures who had never met in the wild and were making this one up. She would stand by the window and watch the ferry do its slow and faithful work and think that the best part of any of this had not been the applause or the lights but the moment in a room when somebody had listened and changed a molecule and everything around it had had to rearrange to make room. She would hold that in the way you hold heat in your pockets when it is January and the town cannot help you with the cold. She would go to school. She would be the person with the chalk. She would hum. She would make weather and let weather be made. She would not forget, because forgetting would have felt like a betrayal and she had had enough of those to last all her lives.
